Child: C h i l d "n. One who  by character of practice shows signs of relationship to or of the influence of another; one closely connected with a place occupation character etc.; as a child of God; a child of the devil; a child of disobedience; a child of toil; a child of the people.

Child: C h i l d "n. A noble youth. See Childe.

Child: C h i l d "n. A young person of either sex. esp. one between infancy and youth; hence  one who exhibits the characteristics of a very young person as innocence obedience trustfulness limited understanding etc.

Child: C h i l d "n. A female infant.

Child: C h i l d "v. i. To give birth; to produce young.

Childbearing: C h i l d b e a r i n g "n. The act of producing or bringing forth children; parturition.

Childbed: C h i l d b e d "n. The state of a woman bringing forth a child  or being in labor; parturition.

Childbirth: C h i l d b i r t h "n. The act of bringing forth a child; travail; labor.

Childcrowing: C h i l d c r o w i n g "n. The crowing noise made by children affected with spasm of the laryngeal muscles; false croup.

Childe: C h i l d e "n. A cognomen formerly prefixed to his name by the oldest son  until he succeeded to his ancestral titles or was knighted; as Childe Roland.

Childed: C h i l d e d "imp. & p. p. of Child

Childed: C h i l d e d "a. Furnished with a child.

Childermas day: C h i l d e r m a s   d a y " A day (December 28) observed by mass or festival in commemoration of the children slain by Herod at Bethlehem; -- called also Holy Innocent's Day.

Childhood: C h i l d h o o d "n. The state of being a child; the time in which persons are children; the condition or time from infancy to puberty.

Childhood: C h i l d h o o d "n. Children  taken collectively.

Childhood: C h i l d h o o d "n. The commencement; the first period.

Childing: C h i l d i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Child

Childing: C h i l d i n g "v. i. Bearing Children; (Fig.) productive; fruitful.

Childish: C h i l d i s h "a. Of  pertaining to befitting or resembling a child.

Childish: C h i l d i s h "a. Puerile; trifling; weak.

Childishly: C h i l d i s h l y "adv. In the manner of a child; in a trifling way; in a weak or foolish manner.

Childishness: C h i l d i s h n e s s "n. The state or quality of being childish; simplicity; harmlessness; weakness of intellect.

Childlessness: C h i l d l e s s n e s s "n. The state of being childless.

Childlike: C h i l d l i k e "a. Resembling a child  or that which belongs to children; becoming a child; meek; submissive; dutiful.

Childly: C h i l d l y "a. Having the character of a child; belonging  or appropriate to a child.

Childly: C h i l d l y "adv. Like a child.

Childness: C h i l d n e s s "n. The manner characteristic of a child.

Children: C h i l d r e n "pl. "of Child

Children: C h i l d r e n "n. pl. of Child.

Childship: C h i l d s h i p "n. The state or relation of being a child.

Chili: C h i l i "n. A kind of red pepper. See Capsicum

Chiliad: C h i l i a d "n. A thousand; the aggregate of a thousand things; especially  a period of a thousand years.

Chiliagon: C h i l i a g o n "n. A plane figure of a thousand angles and sides.

Chiliahedron: C h i l i a h e d r o n "n. A figure bounded by a thousand plane surfaces

Chilian: C h i l i a n "a. Of or pertaining to Chili.

Chilian: C h i l i a n "n. A native or citizen of Chili.

Chilian: C h i l i a n "n. Alt. of Chiliarch

Chiliarch: C h i l i a r c h "n. The commander or chief of a thousand men.

Chiliarchy: C h i l i a r c h y "n. A body consisting of a thousand men.

Chiliasm: C h i l i a s m "n. The millennium.

Chiliasm: C h i l i a s m "n. The doctrine of the personal reign of Christ on earth during the millennium.

Chiliast: C h i l i a s t "n. One who believes in the second coming of Christ to reign on earth a thousand years; a milllenarian.

Chiliastic: C h i l i a s t i c "a. Millenarian.

Chill: C h i l l "n. A moderate but disagreeable degree of cold; a disagreeable sensation of coolness  accompanied with shivering.

Chill: C h i l l "n. A sensation of cold with convulsive shaking of the body  pinched face pale skin and blue lips caused by undue cooling of the body or by nervous excitement or forming the precursor of some constitutional disturbance as of a fever.

Chill: C h i l l "n. A check to enthusiasm or warmth of feeling; discouragement; as  a chill comes over an assembly.

Chill: C h i l l "n. An iron mold or portion of a mold  serving to cool rapidly and so to harden the surface of molten iron brought in contact with it.

Chill: C h i l l "n. The hardened part of a casting  as the tread of a car wheel.

Chill: C h i l l "a. Moderately cold; tending to cause shivering; chilly; raw.

Chill: C h i l l "a. Affected by cold.

Chill: C h i l l "a. Characterized by coolness of manner  feeling etc.; lacking enthusiasm or warmth; formal; distant; as a chill reception.

Chill: C h i l l "a. Discouraging; depressing; dispiriting.

Chill: C h i l l "v. t. To strike with a chill; to make chilly; to cause to shiver; to affect with cold.

Chill: C h i l l "v. t. To check enthusiasm or warmth of feeling of; to depress; to discourage.

Chill: C h i l l "v. t. To produce  by sudden cooling a change of crystallization at or near the surface of so as to increase the hardness; said of cast iron.

Chill: C h i l l "v. i. To become surface-hardened by sudden cooling while solidifying; as  some kinds of cast iron chill to a greater depth than others.

Chilled: C h i l l e d "imp. & p. p. of Chill

Chilled: C h i l l e d "a. Hardened on the surface or edge by chilling; as  chilled iron; a chilled wheel.

Chilled: C h i l l e d "a. Having that cloudiness or dimness of surface that is called blooming.

Chilli: C h i l l i "n. See Chili.

Chilliness: C h i l l i n e s s "n. A state or sensation of being chilly; a disagreeable sensation of coldness.

Chilliness: C h i l l i n e s s "n. A moderate degree of coldness; disagreeable coldness or rawness; as  the chilliness of the air.

Chilliness: C h i l l i n e s s "n. Formality; lack of warmth.

Chilling: C h i l l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Chill

Chilling: C h i l l i n g "a. Making chilly or cold; depressing; discouraging; cold; distant; as  a chilling breeze; a chilling manner.

Chillness: C h i l l n e s s "n. Coolness; coldness; a chill.

Chilly: C h i l l y "a. Moderately cold; cold and raw or damp so as to cause shivering; causing or feeling a disagreeable sensation of cold  or a shivering.

Chilognath: C h i l o g n a t h "n. A myriapod of the order Chilognatha.

Chilognatha: C h i l o g n a t h a "n. pl. One of the two principal orders of myriapods. They have numerous segments  each bearing two pairs of small slender legs which are attached ventrally near together.

Chiloma: C h i l o m a "n. The tumid upper lip of certain mammals  as of a camel.

Chilopod: C h i l o p o d "n. A myriapod of the order Chilopoda.

Chilopoda: C h i l o p o d a "n. pl. One of the orders of myriapods  including the centipeds. They have a single pair of elongated legs attached laterally to each segment; well developed jaws; and a pair of thoracic legs converted into poison fangs. They are insectivorous very active and some species grow to the length of a foot.

Chilostoma: C h i l o s t o m a "n. pl. Alt. of Chilostomata

Chilostomata: C h i l o s t o m a t a "n. pl. An extensive suborder of marine Bryozoa  mostly with calcareous shells. They have a movable lip and a lid to close the aperture of the cells.

Chilostomatous: C h i l o s t o m a t o u s "a. Of or pertaining to the Chilostoma.

Chiltern Hundreds: C h i l t e r n   H u n d r e d s " A tract of crown land in Buckinghamshire and Oxfordshire  England to which is attached the nominal office of steward. As members of Parliament cannot resign when they wish to go out they accept this stewardship which legally vacates their seats.

Chimaera: C h i m a e r a "n. A cartilaginous fish of several species  belonging to the order Holocephali. The teeth are few and large. The head is furnished with appendages and the tail terminates in a point.

Chimaeroid: C h i m a e r o i d "a. Related to  or like the chimaera.

Chimango: C h i m a n g o " A south American carrion buzzard (Milvago chimango). See Caracara.

Chimb: C h i m b "n. The edge of a cask  etc; a chine. See Chine n. 3.

Chimb: C h i m b "v. i. Chime.

Chime: C h i m e "n. See Chine  n. 3.

Chime: C h i m e "n. The harmonious sound of bells  or of musical instruments.

Chime: C h i m e "n. A set of bells musically tuned to each other; specif.  in the pl. the music performed on such a set of bells by hand or produced by mechanism to accompany the striking of the hours or their divisions.

Chime: C h i m e "n. Pleasing correspondence of proportion  relation or sound.

Chime: C h i m e "n. To sound in harmonious accord  as bells.

Chime: C h i m e "n. To be in harmony; to agree; to suit; to harmonize; to correspond; to fall in with.

Chime: C h i m e "n. To join in a conversation; to express assent; -- followed by in or in with.

Chime: C h i m e "n. To make a rude correspondence of sounds; to jingle  as in rhyming.

Chime: C h i m e "v. i. To cause to sound in harmony; to play a tune  as upon a set of bells; to move or strike in harmony.

Chime: C h i m e "v. i. To utter harmoniously; to recite rhythmically.

Chimed: C h i m e d "imp. & p. p. of Chime

Chimer: C h i m e r "n. One who chimes.

Chimera: C h i m e r a "n. A monster represented as vomiting flames  and as having the head of a lion the body of a goat and the tail of a dragon.

Chimera: C h i m e r a "n. A vain  foolish or incongruous fancy or creature of the imagination; as the chimera of an author.

Chimeras: C h i m e r a s "pl. "of Chimera

Chimere: C h i m e r e "n. The upper robe worn by a bishop  to which lawn sleeves are usually attached.

Chimeric: C h i m e r i c "a. Chimerical.

Chimerical: C h i m e r i c a l "a. Merely imaginary; fanciful; fantastic; wildly or vainly conceived; having  or capable of having no existence except in thought; as chimerical projects.

Chimerically: C h i m e r i c a l l y "adv. Wildy; vainly; fancifully.

Chiminage: C h i m i n a g e "n. A toll for passage through a forest.

Chiming: C h i m i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Chime

Chimney: C h i m n e y "n. A fireplace or hearth.

Chimney: C h i m n e y "n. That part of a building which contains the smoke flues; esp. an upright tube or flue of brick or stone  in most cases extending through or above the roof of the building. Often used instead of chimney shaft.

Chimney: C h i m n e y "n. A tube usually of glass  placed around a flame as of a lamp to create a draft and promote combustion.

Chimney: C h i m n e y "n. A body of ore  usually of elongated form extending downward in a vein.

Chimney-breast: C h i m n e y - b r e a s t "n. The horizontal projection of a chimney from the wall in which it is built; -- commonly applied to its projection in the inside of a building only.

Chimney-piece: C h i m n e y - p i e c e "n. A decorative construction around the opening of a fireplace.

Chimneys: C h i m n e y s "pl. "of Chimney

Chimpanzee: C h i m p a n z e e "n. An african ape (Anthropithecus troglodytes or Troglodytes niger) which approaches more nearly to man  in most respects than any other ape. When full grown it is from three to four feet high.

Chin: C h i n "n. The lower extremity of the face below the mouth; the point of the under jaw.

Chin: C h i n "n. The exterior or under surface embraced between the branches of the lower jaw bone  in birds.

Chin cough: C h i n   c o u g h " Whooping cough.

China: C h i n a "n. A country in Eastern Asia.

China: C h i n a "n. China ware  which is the modern popular term for porcelain. See Porcelain.

Chinaldine: C h i n a l d i n e "n. See Quinaldine.

Chinaman: C h i n a m a n "n. A native of China; a Chinese.

Chinamen: C h i n a m e n "pl. "of Chinaman

Chincapin: C h i n c a p i n "n. See Chinquapin.

Chinch: C h i n c h "n. The bedbug (Cimex lectularius).

Chinch: C h i n c h "n. A bug (Blissus leucopterus)  which in the United States is very destructive to grass wheat and other grains; -- also called chiniz chinch bug chink bug. It resembles the bedbug in its disgusting odor.

Chincha: C h i n c h a "n. A south American rodent of the genus Lagotis.

Chinche: C h i n c h e "a. Parsimonious; niggardly.

Chincherie: C h i n c h e r i e "n. Penuriousness.

Chinchilla: C h i n c h i l l a "n. A small rodent (Chinchilla lanigera)  of the size of a large squirrel remarkable for its fine fur which is very soft and of a pearly gray color. It is a native of Peru and Chili.

Chinchilla: C h i n c h i l l a "n. The fur of the chinchilla.

Chinchilla: C h i n c h i l l a "n. A heavy  long-napped tufted woolen cloth.

Chinchona: C h i n c h o n a " Alt. of Chincona

Chincona: C h i n c o n a " See Cinchona.

Chine: C h i n e "n. A chink or cleft; a narrow and deep ravine; as  Shanklin Chine in the Isle of Wight a quarter of a mile long and 230 feet deep.

Chine: C h i n e "n. The backbone or spine of an animal; the back.

Chine: C h i n e "n. A piece of the backbone of an animal  with the adjoining parts cut for cooking. [See Illust. of Beef.]

Chine: C h i n e "n. The edge or rim of a cask  etc. formed by the projecting ends of the staves; the chamfered end of a stave.

Chine: C h i n e "v. t. To cut through the backbone of; to cut into chine pieces.

Chine: C h i n e "v. t. Too chamfer the ends of a stave and form the chine..

Chined: C h i n e d "imp. & p. p. of Chine

Chined: C h i n e d "a. Pertaining to  or having a chine or backbone; -- used in composition.

Chined: C h i n e d "a. Broken in the back.

Chinese: C h i n e s e "a. Of or pertaining to China; peculiar to China.

Chinese: C h i n e s e "n. sing. & pl. A native or natives of China  or one of that yellow race with oblique eyelids who live principally in China.

Chinese: C h i n e s e "n. sing. & pl. The language of China  which is monosyllabic.

Chink: C h i n k "n. A small cleft  rent or fissure of greater length than breadth; a gap or crack; as the chinks of wall.

Chink: C h i n k "v. i. To crack; to open.

Chink: C h i n k "v. t. To cause to open in cracks or fissures.

Chink: C h i n k "v. t. To fill up the chinks of; as  to chink a wall.

Chink: C h i n k "n. A short  sharp sound as of metal struck with a slight degree of violence.

Chink: C h i n k "n. Money; cash.

Chink: C h i n k "v. t. To cause to make a sharp metallic sound  as coins small pieces of metal etc. by bringing them into collision with each other.

Chink: C h i n k "v. i. To make a slight  sharp metallic sound as by the collision of little pieces of money or other small sonorous bodies.

Chinked: C h i n k e d "imp. & p. p. of Chink

Chinking: C h i n k i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Chink

Chinky: C h i n k y "a. Full of chinks or fissures; gaping; opening in narrow clefts.

Chinned: C h i n n e d "a. Having a chin; -- used chiefly in compounds; as  short-chinned.

Chinoidine: C h i n o i d i n e "n. See Quinodine.

Chinoline: C h i n o l i n e "n. See Quinoline.

Chinone: C h i n o n e "n. See Quinone.

Chinook: C h i n o o k "n. One of a tribe of North American Indians now living in the state of Washington  noted for the custom of flattening their skulls. Chinooks also called Flathead Indians.

Chinook: C h i n o o k "n. A warm westerly wind from the country of the Chinooks  sometimes experienced on the slope of the Rocky Mountains in Montana and the adjacent territory.

Chinook: C h i n o o k "n. A jargon of words from various languages (the largest proportion of which is from that of the Chinooks) generally understood by all the Indian tribes of the northwestern territories of the United States.

Chinquapin: C h i n q u a p i n "n. A branching  nut-bearing tree or shrub (Castanea pumila) of North America from six to twenty feet high allied to the chestnut. Also its small sweet edible nat.

Chinse: C h i n s e "v. t. & i. To thrust oakum into (seams or chinks) with a chisel   the point of a knife or a chinsing iron; to calk slightly.

Chinsed: C h i n s e d "imp. & p. p. of Chinse

Chinsing: C h i n s i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Chinse

Chintz: C h i n t z "n. Cotton cloth  printed with flowers and other devices in a number of different colors and often glazed.

Chintzes: C h i n t z e s "pl. "of Chintz

Chioppine: C h i o p p i n e "n. Same as Chopine  n.

Chip: C h i p "v. t. To cut small pieces from; to diminish or reduce to shape  by cutting away a little at a time; to hew.

Chip: C h i p "v. t. To break or crack  or crack off a portion of as of an eggshell in hatching or a piece of crockery.

Chip: C h i p "v. t. To bet  as with chips in the game of poker.

Chip: C h i p "v. i. To break or fly off in small pieces.

Chip: C h i p "n. A piece of wood  stone or other substance separated by an ax chisel or cutting instrument.

Chip: C h i p "n. A fragment or piece broken off; a small piece.

Chip: C h i p "n. Wood or Cuban palm leaf split into slips  or straw plaited in a special manner for making hats or bonnets.

Chip: C h i p "n. Anything dried up  withered or without flavor; -- used contemptuously.

Chip: C h i p "n. One of the counters used in poker and other games.

Chip: C h i p "n. The triangular piece of wood attached to the log line.

Chipmunk: C h i p m u n k "n. A squirrel-like animal of the genus Tamias  sometimes called the striped squirrel chipping squirrel ground squirrel hackee. The common species of the United States is the Tamias striatus.

Chipped: C h i p p e d "imp. & p. p. of Chip

Chipper: C h i p p e r "v. i. To chirp or chirrup.

Chipper: C h i p p e r "a. Lively; cheerful; talkative.

Chippeways: C h i p p e w a y s "n. pl. A tribe of Indians formerly inhabiting the northern and western shores of Lake Superior; -- called also Objibways.

Chipping: C h i p p i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Chip

Chipping: C h i p p i n g "n. A chip; a piece separated by a cutting or graving instrument; a fragment.

Chipping: C h i p p i n g "n. The act or process of cutting or breaking off small pieces  as in dressing iron with a chisel or reducing a timber or block of stone to shape.

Chipping: C h i p p i n g "n. The breaking off in small pieces of the edges of potter's ware  porcelain etc.

Chipping bird: C h i p p i n g   b i r d " The chippy.

Chipping squirrel: C h i p p i n g   s q u i r r e l " See Chipmunk.

Chippy: C h i p p y "a. Abounding in  or resembling chips; dry and tasteless.

Chippy: C h i p p y "n. A small American sparrow (Spizella socialis)  very common near dwelling; -- also called chipping bird and chipping sparrow from its simple note.

Chips: C h i p s "n. A ship's carpenter.

Chiragra: C h i r a g r a "n. Gout in the hand.

Chiragrical: C h i r a g r i c a l "a. Having the gout in the hand  or subject to that disease.

Chiretta: C h i r e t t a "n. A plant (Agathotes Chirayta) found in Northern India  having medicinal properties to the gentian and esteemed as a tonic and febrifuge.

Chirk: C h i r k "v. i. To shriek; to gnash; to utter harsh or shrill cries.

Chirk: C h i r k "v. i. To chirp like a bird.

Chirk: C h i r k "v. t. To cheer; to enliven; as  to chirk one up.

Chirk: C h i r k "v. i. Lively; cheerful; in good spirits.

Chirm: C h i r m "v. i. To chirp or to make a mournful cry  as a bird.

Chirm: C h i r m "n. Clamor  or confused noise; buzzing.

Chirognomy: C h i r o g n o m y "n. The art of judging character by the shape and appearance of the hand.

Chirograph: C h i r o g r a p h "n. A writing which  requiring a counterpart was engrossed twice on the same piece of parchment with a space between in which was written the word chirographum through which the parchment was cut and one part given to each party. It answered to what is now called a charter party.

Chirograph: C h i r o g r a p h "n. The last part of a fine of land  commonly called the foot of the fine.

Chirographer: C h i r o g r a p h e r "n. One who practice the art or business of writing or engrossing.

Chirographer: C h i r o g r a p h e r "n. See chirographist  2.

Chirographic: C h i r o g r a p h i c "a. Alt. of Chirographical

Chirographical: C h i r o g r a p h i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to chirography.

Chirographist: C h i r o g r a p h i s t "n. A chirographer; a writer or engrosser.

Chirographist: C h i r o g r a p h i s t "n. One who tells fortunes by examining the hand.

Chirography: C h i r o g r a p h y "n. The art of writing or engrossing; handwriting; as  skilled in chirography.

Chirography: C h i r o g r a p h y "n. The art of telling fortunes by examining the hand.

Chirogymnast: C h i r o g y m n a s t "n. A mechanical contrivance for exercising the fingers of a pianist.

Chirological: C h i r o l o g i c a l "a. Relating to chirology.

Chirologist: C h i r o l o g i s t "n. One who communicates thoughts by signs made with the hands and fingers.

Chirology: C h i r o l o g y "n. The art or practice of using the manual alphabet or of communicating thoughts by sings made by the hands and fingers; a substitute for spoken or written language in intercourse with the deaf and dumb. See Dactylalogy.

Chiromancer: C h i r o m a n c e r "n. One who practices chiromancy.

Chiromancy: C h i r o m a n c y "n. The art or practice of foretelling events  or of telling the fortunes or the disposition of persons by inspecting the hand; palmistry.

Chiromanist: C h i r o m a n i s t "n. Alt. of Chiromantist

Chiromantic: C h i r o m a n t i c "a. Alt. of Chiromantical

Chiromantical: C h i r o m a n t i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to chiromancy.

Chiromantist: C h i r o m a n t i s t "n. A chiromancer.

Chiromonic: C h i r o m o n i c "a. Relating to chironomy.

Chironomy: C h i r o n o m y "n. The art of moving the hands in oratory or in pantomime; gesture

Chiroplast: C h i r o p l a s t "n. An instrument to guid the hands and fingers of pupils in playing on the piano  etc.

Chiropodist: C h i r o p o d i s t "n. One who treats diseases of the hands and feet; especially  one who removes corns and bunions.

Chiropody: C h i r o p o d y "n. The art of treating diseases of the hands and feet.

Chirosophist: C h i r o s o p h i s t "n. A fortune teller.

Chirp: C h i r p "v. i. To make a shop  sharp cheerful as of small birds or crickets.

Chirp: C h i r p "n. A short  sharp note as of a bird or insect.

Chirper: C h i r p e r "n. One who chirps  or is cheerful.

Chirping: C h i r p i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Chirp

Chirping: C h i r p i n g "a. Cheering; enlivening.

Chirpingly: C h i r p i n g l y "adv. In a chirping manner.

Chirre: C h i r r e "v. i. To coo  as a pigeon.

Chirrup: C h i r r u p "v. t. To quicken or animate by chirping; to cherup.

Chirurgeon: C h i r u r g e o n "n. A surgeon.

Chirurgeonly: C h i r u r g e o n l y "adv. Surgically.

Chirurgic: C h i r u r g i c "a. Alt. of Chirurgical

Chirurgical: C h i r u r g i c a l "a. Surgical

Chisel: C h i s e l "n. A tool with a cutting edge on one end of a metal blade  used in dressing shaping or working in timber stone metal etc.; -- usually driven by a mallet or hammer.

Chisel: C h i s e l "v. t. To cut  pare gouge or engrave with a chisel; as to chisel a block of marble into a statue.

Chisel: C h i s e l "v. t. To cut close  as in a bargain; to cheat.

Chiseled: C h i s e l e d "imp. & p. p. of Chisel

Chisleu: C h i s l e u "n. The ninth month of the Jewish ecclesiastical year  answering to a part of November with a part of December.

Chisley: C h i s l e y "a. Having a large admixture of small pebbles or gravel; -- said of a soil.

Chit: C h i t "n. The embryo or the growing bud of a plant; a shoot; a sprout; as  the chits of Indian corn or of potatoes.

Chit: C h i t "n. A child or babe; as  a forward chit; also a young small or insignificant person or animal.

Chit: C h i t "n. An excrescence on the body  as a wart.

Chit: C h i t "n. A small tool used in cleaving laths.

Chit: C h i t "v. i. To shoot out; to sprout.

Chit: C h i t "3d sing. Chideth.

Chitchat: C h i t c h a t "n. Familiar or trifling talk; prattle.

Chitin: C h i t i n "n. A white amorphous horny substance forming the harder part of the outer integument of insects  crustacea and various other invertebrates; entomolin.

Chitinization: C h i t i n i z a t i o n "n. The process of becoming chitinous.

Chitinous: C h i t i n o u s "a. Having the nature of chitin; consisting of  or containing chitin.

Chiton: C h i t o n "n. An under garment among the ancient Greeks  nearly representing the modern shirt.

Chiton: C h i t o n "n. One of a group of gastropod mollusks  with a shell composed of eight movable dorsal plates. See Polyplacophora.

Chitter: C h i t t e r "v. i. To chirp in a tremulous manner  as a bird.

Chitter: C h i t t e r "v. i. To shiver or chatter with cold.

Chitterling: C h i t t e r l i n g "n. The frill to the breast of a shirt  which when ironed out resembled the small entrails. See Chitterlings.

Chitterlings: C h i t t e r l i n g s "n. pl. The smaller intestines of swine  etc. fried for food.

Chittra: C h i t t r a "n. The axis deer of India.

Chitty: C h i t t y "a. Full of chits or sprouts.

Chitty: C h i t t y "a. Childish; like a babe.

Chivachie: C h i v a c h i e "n. A cavalry raid; hence  a military expedition.

Chivalric: C h i v a l r i c "a. Relating to chivalry; knightly; chivalrous.

Chivalrous: C h i v a l r o u s "a. Pertaining to chivalry or knight-errantry; warlike; heroic; gallant; high-spirited; high-minded; magnanimous.

Chivalrously: C h i v a l r o u s l y "adv. In a chivalrous manner; gallantly; magnanimously.

Chivalry: C h i v a l r y "n. A body or order of cavaliers or knights serving on horseback; illustrious warriors  collectively; cavalry.

Chivalry: C h i v a l r y "n. The dignity or system of knighthood; the spirit  usages or manners of knighthood; the practice of knight-errantry.

Chivalry: C h i v a l r y "n. The qualifications or character of knights  as valor dexterity in arms courtesy etc.

Chivalry: C h i v a l r y "n. A tenure of lands by knight's service; that is  by the condition of a knight's performing service on horseback or of performing some noble or military service to his lord.

Chivalry: C h i v a l r y "n. Exploit.

Chive: C h i v e "n. A filament of a stamen.

Chive: C h i v e "n. A perennial plant (Allium Schoenoprasum)  allied to the onion. The young leaves are used in omelets etc.

Chivied: C h i v i e d "imp. & p. p. of Chivy

Chivy: C h i v y "v. t. To goad  drive hunt throw or pitch.

Chivying: C h i v y i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Chivy

Chlamydate: C h l a m y d a t e "a. Having a mantle; -- applied to certain gastropods.

Chlamydes: C h l a m y d e s "pl. "of Chlamys

Chlamyphore: C h l a m y p h o r e "n. A small South American edentate (Chlamyphorus truncatus  and C. retusus) allied to the armadillo. It is covered with a leathery shell or coat of mail like a cloak attached along the spine.

Chlamys: C h l a m y s "n. A loose and flowing outer garment  worn by the ancient Greeks; a kind of cloak.

Chlamyses: C h l a m y s e s "pl. "of Chlamys

Chloasma: C h l o a s m a "n. A cutaneous affection characterized by yellow or yellowish brown pigmented spots.

Chloral: C h l o r a l "n. A colorless oily liquid  CCl3.CHO of a pungent odor and harsh taste obtained by the action of chlorine upon ordinary or ethyl alcohol.

Chloral: C h l o r a l "n. Chloral hydrate.

Chloralamide: C h l o r a l a m i d e "n. A compound of chloral and formic amide used to produce sleep.

Chloralism: C h l o r a l i s m "n. A morbid condition of the system resulting from excessive use of chloral.

Chloralum: C h l o r a l u m "n. An impure aqueous solution of chloride of aluminium  used as an antiseptic and disinfectant.

Chloranil: C h l o r a n i l "n. A yellow crystalline substance  C6Cl4.O2 regarded as a derivative of quinone obtained by the action of chlorine on certain benzene derivatives as aniline.

Chlorate: C h l o r a t e "n. A salt of chloric acid; as  chlorate of potassium.

Chloraurate: C h l o r a u r a t e "n. See Aurochloride.

Chlorhydric: C h l o r h y d r i c "a. Same as Hydrochloric.

Chlorhydrin: C h l o r h y d r i n "n. One of a class of compounds formed from certain polybasic alcohols (and especially glycerin) by the substitution of chlorine for one or more hydroxyl groups.

Chloric: C h l o r i c "a. Pertaining to  or obtained from chlorine; -- said of those compounds of chlorine in which this element has a valence of five or the next to its highest; as chloric acid HClO3.

Chloridate: C h l o r i d a t e "v. t. To treat or prepare with a chloride  as a plate with chloride of silver for the purposes of photography.

Chloride: C h l o r i d e "n. A binary compound of chlorine with another element or radical; as  chloride of sodium (common salt).

Chloridic: C h l o r i d i c "a. Of or pertaining to a chloride; containing a chloride.

Chloridize: C h l o r i d i z e "v. t. See Chloridate.

Chlorimetry: C h l o r i m e t r y "n. See Chlorometry.

Chlorinate: C h l o r i n a t e "v. t. To treat  or cause to combine with chlorine.

Chlorinated: C h l o r i n a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Chlorinate

Chlorinating: C h l o r i n a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Chlorinate

Chlorination: C h l o r i n a t i o n "n. The act or process of subjecting anything to the action of chlorine; especially  a process for the extraction of gold by exposure of the auriferous material to chlorine gas.

Chlorine: C h l o r i n e "n. One of the elementary substances  commonly isolated as a greenish yellow gas two and one half times as heavy as air of an intensely disagreeable suffocating odor and exceedingly poisonous. It is abundant in nature the most important compound being common salt. It is powerful oxidizing bleaching and disinfecting agent. Symbol Cl. Atomic weight 35.4.

Chloriodic: C h l o r i o d i c "a. Compounded of chlorine and iodine; containing chlorine and iodine.

Chloriodine: C h l o r i o d i n e "n. A compound of chlorine and iodine.

Chlorite: C h l o r i t e "n. The name of a group of minerals  usually of a green color and micaceous to granular in structure. They are hydrous silicates of alumina iron and magnesia.

Chlorite: C h l o r i t e "n. Any salt of chlorous acid; as  chlorite of sodium.

Chloritic: C h l o r i t i c "a. Pertaining to  or containing chlorite; as chloritic sand.

Chlormethane: C h l o r m e t h a n e "n. A colorless gas  CH3Cl of a sweet odor easily condensed to a liquid; -- called also methyl chloride.

Chloro-: C h l o r o - " A prefix denoting that chlorine is an ingredient in the substance named.

Chlorocruorin: C h l o r o c r u o r i n "n. A green substance  supposed to be the cause of the green color of the blood in some species of worms.

Chlorodyne: C h l o r o d y n e "n. A patent anodyne medicine  containing opium chloroform Indian hemp etc.

Chloroform: C h l o r o f o r m "n. A colorless volatile liquid  CHCl3 having an ethereal odor and a sweetish taste formed by treating alcohol with chlorine and an alkali. It is a powerful solvent of wax resin etc. and is extensively used to produce anaesthesia in surgical operations; also externally to alleviate pain.

Chloroform: C h l o r o f o r m "v. t. To treat with chloroform  or to place under its influence.

Chloroformed: C h l o r o f o r m e d "imp. & p. p. of Chloroform

Chloroforming: C h l o r o f o r m i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Chloroform

Chloroleucite: C h l o r o l e u c i t e "n. Same as Chloroplastid.

Chlorometer: C h l o r o m e t e r "n. An instrument to test the decoloring or bleaching power of chloride of lime.

Chlorometry: C h l o r o m e t r y "n. The process of testing the bleaching power of any combination of chlorine.

Chloropal: C h l o r o p a l "n. A massive mineral  greenish in color and opal-like in appearance. It is essentially a hydrous silicate of iron.

Chloropeptic: C h l o r o p e p t i c "a. Of or pertaining to an acid more generally called pepsin-hydrochloric acid.

Chlorophane: C h l o r o p h a n e "n. A variety of fluor spar  which when heated gives a beautiful emerald green light.

Chlorophane: C h l o r o p h a n e "n. The yellowish green pigment in the inner segment of the cones of the retina. See Chromophane.

Chlorophyll: C h l o r o p h y l l "n. Literally  leaf green; a green granular matter formed in the cells of the leaves (and other parts exposed to light) of plants to which they owe their green color and through which all ordinary assimilation of plant food takes place. Similar chlorophyll granules have been found in the tissues of the lower animals.

Chloroplastid: C h l o r o p l a s t i d "n. A granule of chlorophyll; -- also called chloroleucite.

Chloroplatinic: C h l o r o p l a t i n i c "a. See Platinichloric.

Chlorosis: C h l o r o s i s "n. The green sickness; an anaemic disease of young women  characterized by a greenish or grayish yellow hue of the skin weakness palpitation etc.

Chlorosis: C h l o r o s i s "n. A disease in plants  causing the flowers to turn green or the leaves to lose their normal green color.

Chlorotic: C h l o r o t i c "a. Pertaining to  or affected by chlorosis.

Chlorous: C h l o r o u s "a. Of  pertaining to or derived from chlorine; -- said of those compounds of chlorine in which this element has a valence of three the next lower than in chloric compounds; as chlorous acid HClO2.

Chlorous: C h l o r o u s "a. Pertaining to  or resembling the electro-negative character of chlorine; hence electro-negative; -- opposed to basylous or zincous.

Chlorpicrin: C h l o r p i c r i n "n. A heavy  colorless liquid CCl3.NO2 of a strong pungent odor obtained by subjecting picric acid to the action of chlorine.

Chloruret: C h l o r u r e t "n. A chloride.

Choak: C h o a k "v. t. & i. See Choke.

Choanoid: C h o a n o i d "a. Funnel-shaped; -- applied particularly to a hollow muscle attached to the ball of the eye in many reptiles and mammals.

Chocard: C h o c a r d "n. The chough.

Chock: C h o c k "v. t. To stop or fasten  as with a wedge or block; to scotch; as to chock a wheel or cask.

Chock: C h o c k "v. i. To fill up  as a cavity.

Chock: C h o c k "n. A wedge  or block made to fit in any space which it is desired to fill esp. something to steady a cask or other body or prevent it from moving by fitting into the space around or beneath it.

Chock: C h o c k "n. A heavy casting of metal  usually fixed near the gunwale. It has two short horn-shaped arms curving inward between which ropes or hawsers may pass for towing mooring etc.

Chock: C h o c k "adv. Entirely; quite; as  chock home; chock aft.

Chock: C h o c k "v. t. To encounter.

Chock: C h o c k "n. An encounter.

Chock-full: C h o c k - f u l l "a. Quite full; choke-full.

Chockablock: C h o c k a b l o c k "a. Hoisted as high as the tackle will admit; brought close together  as the two blocks of a tackle in hoisting.

Chocked: C h o c k e d "imp. & p. p. of Chock

Chocking: C h o c k i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Chock

Chocolate: C h o c o l a t e "n. A paste or cake composed of the roasted seeds of the Theobroma Cacao ground and mixed with other ingredients  usually sugar and cinnamon or vanilla.

Chocolate: C h o c o l a t e "n. The beverage made by dissolving a portion of the paste or cake in boiling water or milk.

Choctaws: C h o c t a w s "n. pl. A tribe of North American Indians (Southern Appalachian)  in early times noted for their pursuit of agriculture and for living at peace with the white settlers. They are now one of the civilized tribes of the Indian Territory.

Chode: C h o d e " the old imp. of chide. See Chide.

Chogset: C h o g s e t "n. See Cunner.

Choice: C h o i c e "n. Act of choosing; the voluntary act of selecting or separating from two or more things that which is preferred; the determination of the mind in preferring one thing to another; election.

Choice: C h o i c e "n. The power or opportunity of choosing; option.

Choice: C h o i c e "n. Care in selecting; judgment or skill in distinguishing what is to be preferred  and in giving a preference; discrimination.

Choice: C h o i c e "n. A sufficient number to choose among.

Choice: C h o i c e "n. The thing or person chosen; that which is approved and selected in preference to others; selection.

Choice: C h o i c e "n. The best part; that which is preferable.

Choice: C h o i c e "superl. Worthly of being chosen or preferred; select; superior; precious; valuable.

Choice: C h o i c e "superl. Preserving or using with care  as valuable; frugal; -- used with of; as to be choice of time or of money.

Choice: C h o i c e "superl. Selected with care  and due attention to preference; deliberately chosen.

Choiceful: C h o i c e f u l "a. Making choices; fickle.

Choicely: C h o i c e l y "adv. With care in choosing; with nice regard to preference.

Choicely: C h o i c e l y "adv. In a preferable or excellent manner; excellently; eminently.

Choiceness: C h o i c e n e s s "n. The quality of being of particular value or worth; nicely; excellence.

Choir: C h o i r "n. A band or organized company of singers  especially in church service.

Choir: C h o i r "n. That part of a church appropriated to the singers.

Choir: C h o i r "n. The chancel.

Choke: C h o k e "v. t. To render unable to breathe by filling  pressing upon or squeezing the windpipe; to stifle; to suffocate; to strangle.

Choke: C h o k e "v. t. To obstruct by filling up or clogging any passage; to block up.

Choke: C h o k e "v. t. To hinder or check  as growth expansion progress etc.; to stifle.

Choke: C h o k e "v. t. To affect with a sense of strangulation by passion or strong feeling.

Choke: C h o k e "v. t. To make a choke  as in a cartridge or in the bore of the barrel of a shotgun.

Choke: C h o k e "v. i. To have the windpipe stopped; to have a spasm of the throat  caused by stoppage or irritation of the windpipe; to be strangled.

Choke: C h o k e "v. i. To be checked  as if by choking; to stick.

Choke: C h o k e "n. A stoppage or irritation of the windpipe  producing the feeling of strangulation.

Choke: C h o k e "n. The tied end of a cartridge.

Choke: C h o k e "n. A constriction in the bore of a shotgun  case of a rocket etc.

Choke damp: C h o k e   d a m p " See Carbonic acid  under Carbonic.

Choke pear: C h o k e   p e a r " A kind of pear that has a rough  astringent taste and is swallowed with difficulty or which contracts the mucous membrane of the mouth.

Choke pear: C h o k e   p e a r " A sarcasm by which one is put to silence; anything that can not be answered.

Choke-full: C h o k e - f u l l "a. Full to the brim; quite full; chock-full.

Choke-strap: C h o k e - s t r a p "n. A strap leading from the bellyband to the lower part of the collar  to keep the collar in place.

Chokeberry: C h o k e b e r r y "n. The small apple-shaped or pear-shaped fruit of an American shrub (Pyrus arbutifolia) growing in damp thickets; also  the shrub.

Chokecherry: C h o k e c h e r r y "n. The astringent fruit of a species of wild cherry (Prunus Virginiana); also  the bush or tree which bears such fruit.

Choked: C h o k e d "imp. & p. p. of Choke

Chokedar: C h o k e d a r "n. A watchman; an officer of customs or police.

Choker: C h o k e r "n. One who  or that which chokes.

Choker: C h o k e r "n. A stiff wide cravat; a stock.

Choking: C h o k i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Choke

Choking: C h o k i n g "a. That chokes; producing the feeling of strangulation.

Choking: C h o k i n g "a. Indistinct in utterance  as the voice of a person affected with strong emotion.

Choky Chokey: C h o k y   C h o k e y "a. Tending to choke or suffocate  or having power to suffocate.

Choky Chokey: C h o k y   C h o k e y "a. Inclined to choke  as a person affected with strong emotion.

Cholaemaa: C h o l a e m a a "n. A disease characterized by severe nervous symptoms  dependent upon the presence of the constituents of the bile in the blood.

Cholagogue: C h o l a g o g u e "a. Promoting the discharge of bile from the system.

Cholagogue: C h o l a g o g u e "n. An agent which promotes the discharge of bile from the system.

Cholate: C h o l a t e "n. A salt of cholic acid; as  sodium cholate.

Cholecystis: C h o l e c y s t i s "n. The gall bladder.

Cholecystotomy: C h o l e c y s t o t o m y "n. The operation of making an opening in the gall bladder  as for the removal of a gallstone.

Choledology: C h o l e d o l o g y "n. A treatise on the bile and bilary organs.

Choleic: C h o l e i c "a. Pertaining to  or obtained from bile; as choleic acid.

Choler: C h o l e r "n. The bile; -- formerly supposed to be the seat and cause of irascibility.

Choler: C h o l e r "n. Irritation of the passions; anger; wrath.

Cholera: C h o l e r a "n. One of several diseases affecting the digestive and intestinal tract and more or less dangerous to life  esp. the one commonly called Asiatic cholera.

Choleraic: C h o l e r a i c "a. Relating to  or resulting from or resembling cholera.

Choleric: C h o l e r i c "a. Abounding with  or producing choler or bile.

Choleric: C h o l e r i c "a. Easily irritated; irascible; inclined to anger.

Choleric: C h o l e r i c "a. Angry; indicating anger; excited by anger.

Cholericly: C h o l e r i c l y "adv. In a choleric manner; angrily.

Choleriform: C h o l e r i f o r m "a. Resembling cholera.

Cholerine: C h o l e r i n e "n. The precursory symptoms of cholera.

Cholerine: C h o l e r i n e "n. The first stage of epidemic cholera.

Cholerine: C h o l e r i n e "n. A mild form of cholera.

Choleroid: C h o l e r o i d "a. Choleriform.

Cholesteric: C h o l e s t e r i c "a. Pertaining to cholesterin  or obtained from it; as cholesteric acid.

Cholesterin: C h o l e s t e r i n "n. A white  fatty crystalline substance tasteless and odorless found in animal and plant products and tissue and especially in nerve tissue in the bile and in gallstones.

Choliamb: C h o l i a m b "n. Alt. of Choliambic

Choliambic: C h o l i a m b i c "n. A verse having an iambus in the fifth place  and a spondee in the sixth or last.

Cholic: C h o l i c "a. Alt. of Cholinic

Choline: C h o l i n e "n. See Neurine.

Cholinic: C h o l i n i c "a. Pertaining to  or obtained from the bile.

Cholochrome: C h o l o c h r o m e "n. See Bilirubin.

Cholophaein: C h o l o p h a e i n "n. See Bilirubin.

Choltry: C h o l t r y "n. A Hindoo caravansary.

Chomp: C h o m p "v. i. To chew loudly and greedily; to champ.

Chondrification: C h o n d r i f i c a t i o n "n. Formation of  or conversion into cartilage.

Chondrify: C h o n d r i f y "v. t. & i. To convert  or be converted into cartilage.

Chondrigen: C h o n d r i g e n "n. The chemical basis of cartilage  converted by long boiling in water into a gelatinous body called chondrin.

Chondrigenous: C h o n d r i g e n o u s "a. Affording chondrin.

Chondrin: C h o n d r i n "n. A colorless  amorphous nitrogenous substance tasteless and odorless formed from cartilaginous tissue by long-continued action of boiling water. It is similar to gelatin and is a large ingredient of commercial gelatin.

Chondrite: C h o n d r i t e "n. A meteoric stone characterized by the presence of chondrules.

Chondritic: C h o n d r i t i c "a. Granular; pertaining to  or having the granular structure characteristic of the class of meteorites called chondrites.

Chondritis: C h o n d r i t i s "n. An inflammation of cartilage.

Chondro-: C h o n d r o - " A combining form meaning a grain  granular granular cartilage cartilaginous; as the chondrocranium the cartilaginous skull of the lower vertebrates and of embryos.

Chondrodite: C h o n d r o d i t e "n. A fluosilicate of magnesia and iron  yellow to red in color often occurring in granular form in a crystalline limestone.

Chondroganoidea: C h o n d r o g a n o i d e a "n. An order of ganoid fishes  including the sturgeons; -- so called on account of their cartilaginous skeleton.

Chondrogen: C h o n d r o g e n "n. Same as Chondrigen.

Chondrogenesis: C h o n d r o g e n e s i s "n. The development of cartilage.

Chondroid: C h o n d r o i d "a. Resembling cartilage.

Chondrology: C h o n d r o l o g y "n. The science which treats of cartilages.

Chondroma: C h o n d r o m a "n. A cartilaginous tumor or growth.

Chondromata: C h o n d r o m a t a "pl. "of Chondroma

Chondrometer: C h o n d r o m e t e r "n. A steelyard for weighting grain.

Chondropterygian: C h o n d r o p t e r y g i a n "a. Having a cartilaginous skeleton.

Chondropterygian: C h o n d r o p t e r y g i a n "n. One of the Chondropterygii.

Chondropterygii: C h o n d r o p t e r y g i i "n. pl. A group of fishes  characterized by cartilaginous fins and skeleton. It includes both ganoids (sturgeons etc.) and selachians (sharks) but is now often restricted to the latter.

Chondrostei: C h o n d r o s t e i "n. pl. An order of fishes  including the sturgeons; -- so named because the skeleton is cartilaginous.

Chondrotomy: C h o n d r o t o m y "n. The dissection of cartilages.

Chondrule: C h o n d r u l e "n. A peculiar rounded granule of some mineral  usually enstatite or chrysolite found imbedded more or less abundantly in the mass of many meteoric stones which are hence called chondrites.

Choose: C h o o s e "v. t. To make choice of; to select; to take by way of preference from two or more objects offered; to elect; as  to choose the least of two evils.

Chop: C h o p "v. t. To seize or devour greedily; -- with up.

Chop: C h o p "v. i. To do something suddenly with an unexpected motion; to catch or attempt to seize.

Chop: C h o p "v. i. To interrupt; -- with in or out.

Chop: C h o p "n. The act of chopping; a stroke.

Chop: C h o p "n. A piece chopped off; a slice or small piece  especially of meat; as a mutton chop.

Chop: C h o p "n. A crack or cleft. See Chap.

Chop: C h o p "n. A jaw of an animal; -- commonly in the pl. See Chops.

Chop: C h o p "n. A movable jaw or cheek  as of a wooden vise.

Chop: C h o p "n. The land at each side of the mouth of a river  harbor or channel; as East Chop or West Chop. See Chops.

Chop: C h o p "n. Quality; brand; as  silk of the first chop.

Chop: C h o p "n. A permit or clearance.

Chopchurch: C h o p c h u r c h "n. An exchanger or an exchange of benefices.

Chopfallen: C h o p f a l l e n "a. Having the lower chop or jaw depressed; hence  crestfallen; dejected; dispirited; downcast. See Chapfallen.

Chopin: C h o p i n "n. A liquid measure formerly used in France and Great Britain  varying from half a pint to a wine quart.

Chopine: C h o p i n e "n. A clog  or patten having a very thick sole or in some cases raised upon a stilt to a height of a foot or more.

Chopping: C h o p p i n g "a. Stout or plump; large.

Chopping: C h o p p i n g "a. Shifting or changing suddenly  as the wind; also having tumbling waves dashing against each other; as a chopping sea.

Chopping: C h o p p i n g "n. Act of cutting by strokes.

Choppy: C h o p p y "a. Full of cracks.

Choppy: C h o p p y "a. Rough  with short tumultuous waves; as a choppy sea.

Chops: C h o p s "n. pl. The sides or capes at the mouth of a river  channel harbor or bay; as the chops of the English Channel.

Chopstick: C h o p s t i c k "n. One of two small sticks of wood  ivory etc. used by the Chinese and Japanese to convey food to the mouth.

Choragic: C h o r a g i c "a. Of or pertaining to a choragus.

Choragus: C h o r a g u s "n. A chorus leader; esp. one who provided at his own expense and under his own supervision one of the choruses for the musical contents at Athens.

Chorology: C h o r o l o g y "n. The science which treats of the laws of distribution of living organisms over the earth's surface as to latitude  altitude locality etc.

Chorometry: C h o r o m e t r y "n. The art of surveying a region or district.

Chorus: C h o r u s "n. A band of singers and dancers.

Chorus: C h o r u s "n. A company of persons supposed to behold what passed in the acts of a tragedy  and to sing the sentiments which the events suggested in couplets or verses between the acts; also that which was thus sung by the chorus.

Chorus: C h o r u s "n. An interpreter in a dumb show or play.

Chorus: C h o r u s "n. A company of singers singing in concert.

Chorus: C h o r u s "n. A composition of two or more parts  each of which is intended to be sung by a number of voices.

Chorus: C h o r u s "n. Parts of a song or hymn recurring at intervals  as at the end of stanzas; also a company of singers who join with the singer or choir in singer or choir in singing such parts.

Chorus: C h o r u s "n. The simultaneous of a company in any noisy demonstration; as  a Chorus of shouts and catcalls.

Choses: C h o s e s "pl. "of Chose

Chouan: C h o u a n "n. One of the royalist insurgents in western France (Brittany  etc.) during and after the French revolution.

Chough: C h o u g h "n. A bird of the Crow family (Fregilus graculus) of Europe. It is of a black color  with a long slender curved bill and red legs; -- also called chauk chauk-daw chocard Cornish chough red-legged crow. The name is also applied to several allied birds as the Alpine chough.

Chouicha: C h o u i c h a "n. The salmon of the Columbia River or California. See Quinnat.

Chouka: C h o u k a "n. The Indian four-horned antelope; the chikara.

Chouse: C h o u s e "n. A swindler.
