Couage: C o u a g e "v. t. To inspire with courage.

Coucal: C o u c a l "n. A large  Old World ground cuckoo of the genus Centropus of several species.

Couch: C o u c h "v. t. To lay upon a bed or other resting place.

Couch: C o u c h "v. t. To arrange or dispose as in a bed; -- sometimes followed by the reflexive pronoun.

Couch: C o u c h "v. t. To lay or deposit in a bed or layer; to bed.

Couch: C o u c h "v. t. To transfer (as sheets of partly dried pulp) from the wire cloth mold to a felt blanket  for further drying.

Couch: C o u c h "v. t. To conceal; to include or involve darkly.

Couch: C o u c h "v. t. To arrange; to place; to inlay.

Couch: C o u c h "v. t. To put into some form of language; to express; to phrase; -- used with in and under.

Couch: C o u c h "v. t. To treat by pushing down or displacing the opaque lens with a needle; as  to couch a cataract.

Couch: C o u c h "v. i. To lie down or recline  as on a bed or other place of rest; to repose; to lie.

Couch: C o u c h "v. i. To lie down for concealment; to hide; to be concealed; to be included or involved darkly.

Couch: C o u c h "v. i. To bend the body  as in reverence pain labor etc.; to stoop; to crouch.

Couch: C o u c h "v. t. A bed or place for repose or sleep; particularly  in the United States a lounge.

Couch: C o u c h "v. t. Any place for repose  as the lair of a beast etc.

Couch: C o u c h "v. t. A mass of steeped barley spread upon a floor to germinate  in malting; or the floor occupied by the barley; as couch of malt.

Couch: C o u c h "v. t. A preliminary layer  as of color size etc.

Couch grass: C o u c h   g r a s s " See Quitch grass.

Couchancy: C o u c h a n c y "n. State of lying down for repose.

Couchant: C o u c h a n t "v. t. Lying down with head erect; squatting.

Couchant: C o u c h a n t "v. t. Lying down with the head raised  which distinguishes the posture of couchant from that of dormant or sleeping; -- said of a lion or other beast.

Couche: C o u c h e "v. t. Not erect; inclined; -- said of anything that is usually erect  as an escutcheon.

Couche: C o u c h e "v. t. Lying on its side; thus  a chevron couche is one which emerges from one side of the escutcheon and has its apex on the opposite side or at the fess point.

Couched: C o u c h e d "imp. & p. p. of Couch

Couched: C o u c h e d "a. Same as Couch/.

Couchee: C o u c h e e "v. t. A reception held at the time of going to bed  as by a sovereign or great prince.

Coucher: C o u c h e r "n. One who couches.

Coucher: C o u c h e r "n. One who couches paper.

Coucher: C o u c h e r "n. A factor or agent resident in a country for traffic.

Coucher: C o u c h e r "n. The book in which a corporation or other body registers its particular acts.

Couching: C o u c h i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Couch

Couching: C o u c h i n g "n. The operation of putting down or displacing the opaque lens in cataract.

Couching: C o u c h i n g "n. Embroidering by laying the materials upon the surface of the foundation  instead of drawing them through.

Couchless: C o u c h l e s s "a. Having no couch or bed.

Coudee: C o u d e e "n. A measure of length; the distance from the elbow to the end of the middle finger; a cubit.

Cougar: C o u g a r "n. An American feline quadruped (Felis concolor)  resembling the African panther in size and habits. Its color is tawny without spots; hence writers often called it the American lion. Called also puma panther mountain lion and catamount. See Puma.

Cough: C o u g h "v. i. To expel air  or obstructing or irritating matter from the lungs or air passages in a noisy and violent manner.

Cough: C o u g h "v. t. To expel from the lungs or air passages by coughing; -- followed by up; as  to cough up phlegm.

Cough: C o u g h "v. t. To bring to a specified state by coughing; as  he coughed himself hoarse.

Cough: C o u g h "v. i. A sudden  noisy and violent expulsion of air from the chest caused by irritation in the air passages or by the reflex action of nervous or gastric disorder etc.

Cough: C o u g h "v. i. The more or less frequent repetition of coughing  constituting a symptom of disease.

Coughed: C o u g h e d "imp. & p. p. of Cough

Cougher: C o u g h e r "n. One who coughs.

Coughing: C o u g h i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Cough

Couhage: C o u h a g e "n. See Cowhage.

Could: C o u l d "imp. of Can

Could: C o u l d "imp. Was  should be or would be able capable or susceptible. Used as an auxiliary in the past tense or in the conditional present.

Coulee: C o u l e e "n. A stream

Coulee: C o u l e e "n. a stream of lava. Also  in the Western United States the bed of a stream even if dry when deep and having inclined sides; distinguished from a ca on which has precipitous sides.

Coulisse: C o u l i s s e "n. A piece of timber having a groove in which something glides.

Coulisse: C o u l i s s e "n. One of the side scenes of the stage in a theater  or the space included between the side scenes.

Couloir: C o u l o i r "n. A deep gorge; a gully.

Couloir: C o u l o i r "n. A dredging machine for excavating canals  etc.

Coulomb: C o u l o m b "n. The standard unit of quantity in electrical measurements. It is the quantity of electricity conveyed in one second by the current produced by an electro-motive force of one volt acting in a circuit having a resistance of one ohm  or the quantity transferred by one ampere in one second. Formerly called weber.

Coulter: C o u l t e r "n. Same as Colter.

Coulterneb: C o u l t e r n e b "n. The puffin.

Coumaric: C o u m a r i c "a. Relating to  derived from or like the Dipterix odorata a tree of Guiana.

Coumarin: C o u m a r i n "n. The concrete essence of the tonka bean  the fruit of Dipterix (formerly Coumarouna) odorata and consisting essentially of coumarin proper which is a white crystalline substance C9H6O2 of vanilla-like odor regarded as an anhydride of coumaric acid and used in flavoring. Coumarin in also made artificially.

Council: C o u n c i l "n. An assembly of men summoned or convened for consultation  deliberation or advice; as a council of physicians for consultation in a critical case.

Council: C o u n c i l "n. A body of man elected or appointed to constitute an advisory or a legislative assembly; as  a governor's council; a city council.

Council: C o u n c i l "n. Act of deliberating; deliberation; consultation.

Councilist: C o u n c i l i s t "n. One who belong to a council; one who gives an opinion.

Councilman: C o u n c i l m a n "n. A member of a council  especially of the common council of a city; a councilor.

Councilmen: C o u n c i l m e n "pl. "of Councilman

Councilor: C o u n c i l o r "n. A member of a council.

Counsel: C o u n s e l "n. Interchange of opinions; mutual advising; consultation.

Counsel: C o u n s e l "n. Examination of consequences; exercise of deliberate judgment; prudence.

Counsel: C o u n s e l "n. Result of consultation; advice; instruction.

Counsel: C o u n s e l "n. Deliberate purpose; design; intent; scheme; plan.

Counsel: C o u n s e l "n. A secret opinion or purpose; a private matter.

Counsel: C o u n s e l "n. One who gives advice  especially in legal matters; one professionally engaged in the trial or management of a cause in court; also collectively the legal advocates united in the management of a case; as the defendant has able counsel.

Counsel: C o u n s e l "v. t. To give advice to; to advice  admonish or instruct as a person.

Counsel: C o u n s e l "v. t. To advise or recommend  as an act or course.

Counselable: C o u n s e l a b l e "a. Willing to receive counsel or follow advice.

Counselable: C o u n s e l a b l e "a. Suitable to be advised; advisable  wise.

Counseled: C o u n s e l e d "imp. & p. p. of Counsel

Counseling: C o u n s e l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Counsel

Counselled: C o u n s e l l e d " of Counsel

Counselling: C o u n s e l l i n g " of Counsel

Counselor: C o u n s e l o r "n. One who counsels; an adviser.

Counselor: C o u n s e l o r "n. A member of council; one appointed to advise a sovereign or chief magistrate. [See under Consilor.]

Counselor: C o u n s e l o r "n. One whose profession is to give advice in law  and manage causes for clients in court; a barrister.

Counselorship: C o u n s e l o r s h i p "n. The function and rank or office of a counselor.

Count: C o u n t "v. t. To tell or name one by one  or by groups for the purpose of ascertaining the whole number of units in a collection; to number; to enumerate; to compute; to reckon.

Count: C o u n t "v. t. To place to an account; to ascribe or impute; to consider or esteem as belonging.

Count: C o u n t "v. t. To esteem; to account; to reckon; to think  judge or consider.

Count: C o u n t "v. i. To number or be counted; to possess value or carry weight; hence  to increase or add to the strength or influence of some party or interest; as every vote counts; accidents count for nothing.

Count: C o u n t "v. i. To reckon; to rely; to depend; -- with on or upon.

Count: C o u n t "v. i. To take account or note; -- with

Count: C o u n t "v. i. To plead orally; to argue a matter in court; to recite a count.

Count: C o u n t "v. t. The act of numbering; reckoning; also  the number ascertained by counting.

Count: C o u n t "v. t. An object of interest or account; value; estimation.

Count: C o u n t "v. t. A formal statement of the plaintiff's case in court; in a more technical and correct sense  a particular allegation or charge in a declaration or indictment separately setting forth the cause of action or prosecution.

Count: C o u n t "n. A nobleman on the continent of Europe  equal in rank to an English earl.

Count-wheel: C o u n t - w h e e l "n. The wheel in a clock which regulates the number of strokes.

Countable: C o u n t a b l e "a. Capable of being numbered.

Counted: C o u n t e d "imp. & p. p. of Count

Countenance: C o u n t e n a n c e "v. t. To encourage; to favor; to approve; to aid; to abet.

Countenance: C o u n t e n a n c e "v. t. To make a show of; to pretend.

Countenanced: C o u n t e n a n c e d "imp. & p. p. of Countenance

Countenancer: C o u n t e n a n c e r "n. One who countenances  favors or supports.

Countenancing: C o u n t e n a n c i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Countenance

Counter: C o u n t e r "adv. A prefix meaning contrary  opposite in opposition; as counteract counterbalance countercheck. See Counter adv. & a.

Counter: C o u n t e r "v. t. One who counts  or reckons up; a calculator; a reckoner.

Counter: C o u n t e r "v. t. A piece of metal  ivory wood or bone used in reckoning in keeping account of games etc.

Counter: C o u n t e r "v. t. Money; coin; -- used in contempt.

Counter: C o u n t e r "v. t. A prison; either of two prisons formerly in London.

Counter: C o u n t e r "v. t. A telltale; a contrivance attached to an engine  printing press or other machine for the purpose of counting the revolutions or the pulsations.

Counter: C o u n t e r "v. t. A table or board on which money is counted and over which business is transacted; a long  narrow table or bench on which goods are laid for examination by purchasers or on which they are weighed or measured.

Counter: C o u n t e r "adv. Contrary; in opposition; in an opposite direction; contrariwise; -- used chiefly with run or go.

Counter: C o u n t e r "adv. In the wrong way; contrary to the right course; as  a hound that runs counter.

Counter: C o u n t e r "adv. At or against the front or face.

Counter: C o u n t e r "a. Contrary; opposite; contrasted; opposed; adverse; antagonistic; as  a counter current; a counter revolution; a counter poison; a counter agent; counter fugue.

Counter: C o u n t e r "adv. The after part of a vessel's body  from the water line to the stern -- below and somewhat forward of the stern proper.

Counter: C o u n t e r "adv. Same as Contra. Formerly used to designate any under part which served for contrast to a principal part  but now used as equivalent to counter tenor.

Counter: C o u n t e r "adv. The breast  or that part of a horse between the shoulders and under the neck.

Counter: C o u n t e r "adv. The back leather or heel part of a boot.

Counter: C o u n t e r "n. An encounter.

Counter: C o u n t e r "v. i. To return a blow while receiving one  as in boxing.

Counter brace: C o u n t e r   b r a c e " The brace of the fore-topsail on the leeward side of a vessel.

Counter brace: C o u n t e r   b r a c e " A brace  in a framed structure which resists a strain of a character opposite to that which a main brace is designed to receive.

Counter tenor: C o u n t e r   t e n o r " One of the middle parts in music  between the tenor and the treble; high tenor.

Counter weight: C o u n t e r   w e i g h t "n. A counterpoise.

Counter-compony: C o u n t e r - c o m p o n y "a. See Compony.

Counter-couchant: C o u n t e r - c o u c h a n t "a. Lying down  with their heads in opposite directions; -- said of animals borne in a coat of arms.

Counter-courant: C o u n t e r - c o u r a n t "a. Running in opposite directions; -- said of animals borne in a coast of arms.

Counter-paly: C o u n t e r - p a l y "a. Paly  and then divided fesswise so that each vertical piece is cut into two having the colors used alternately or counterchanged. Thus the escutcheon in the illustration may also be blazoned paly of six per fess counterchanged argent and azure.

Counter-roll: C o u n t e r - r o l l "n. A duplicate roll (record or account) kept by an officer as a check upon another officer's roll.

Counter-salient: C o u n t e r - s a l i e n t "a. Leaping from each other; -- said of two figures on a coast of arms.

Counteract: C o u n t e r a c t "v. t. To act in opposition to; to hinder  defeat or frustrate by contrary agency or influence; as to counteract the effect of medicines; to counteract good advice.

Counteracted: C o u n t e r a c t e d "imp. & p. p. of Counteract

Counteractibely: C o u n t e r a c t i b e l y "adv. By counteraction.

Counteracting: C o u n t e r a c t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Counteract

Counteraction: C o u n t e r a c t i o n "n. Action in opposition; hindrance resistance.

Counteractive: C o u n t e r a c t i v e "a. Tending to counteract.

Counteractive: C o u n t e r a c t i v e "n. One who  or that which counteracts.

Counterbalance: C o u n t e r b a l a n c e "v. t. To oppose with an equal weight or power; to counteract the power or effect of; to countervail; to equiponderate; to balance.

Counterbalance: C o u n t e r b a l a n c e "n. A weight  power or agency acting against or balancing another

Counterbalance: C o u n t e r b a l a n c e "n. A mass of metal in one side of a driving wheel or fly wheel  to balance the weight of a crank pin etc. on the opposite side of the wheel

Counterbalance: C o u n t e r b a l a n c e "n. A counterpoise to balance the weight of anything  as of a drawbridge or a scale beam.

Counterbalanced: C o u n t e r b a l a n c e d "imp. & p. p. of Counterbalance

Counterbalancing: C o u n t e r b a l a n c i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Counterbalance

Counterbore: C o u n t e r b o r e "n. A flat-bottomed cylindrical enlargement of the mouth of a hole  usually of slight depth as for receiving a cylindrical screw head.

Counterbore: C o u n t e r b o r e "n. A kind of pin drill with the cutting edge or edges normal to the axis; -- used for enlarging a hole  or for forming a flat-bottomed recess at its mouth.

Counterbore: C o u n t e r b o r e "v. t. To form a counterbore in  by boring turning or drilling; to enlarge as a hole by means of a counterbore.

Counterbrace: C o u n t e r b r a c e "v. t. To brace in opposite directions; as  to counterbrace the yards i. e. to brace the head yards one way and the after yards another.

Counterbrace: C o u n t e r b r a c e "v. t. To brace in such a way that opposite strains are resisted; to apply counter braces to.

Counterbuff: C o u n t e r b u f f "v. t. To strike or drive back or in an opposite direction; to stop by a blow or impulse in front.

Counterbuff: C o u n t e r b u f f "n. A blow in an opposite direction; a stroke that stops motion or cause a recoil.

Countercast: C o u n t e r c a s t "n. A trick; a delusive contrivance.

Countercaster: C o u n t e r c a s t e r "n. A caster of accounts; a reckoner; a bookkeeper; -- used contemptuously.

Counterchange: C o u n t e r c h a n g e "v. t. To give and receive; to cause to change places; to exchange.

Counterchange: C o u n t e r c h a n g e "v. t. To checker; to diversify  as in heraldic counterchanging. See Counterchaged a. 2.

Counterchange: C o u n t e r c h a n g e "n. Exchange; reciprocation.

Counterchanged: C o u n t e r c h a n g e d "imp. & p. p. of Counterchange

Counterchanged: C o u n t e r c h a n g e d "a. Exchanged.

Counterchanged: C o u n t e r c h a n g e d "a. Having the tinctures exchanged mutually; thus  if the field is divided palewise or and azure and cross is borne counterchanged that part of the cross which comes on the azure side will be or and that on the or side will be azure.

Counterchanging: C o u n t e r c h a n g i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Counterchange

Countercharge: C o u n t e r c h a r g e "n. An opposing charge.

Countercharm: C o u n t e r c h a r m "v. t. To destroy the effect of a charm upon.

Countercharm: C o u n t e r c h a r m "n. That which has the power of destroying the effect of a charm.

Countercharmed: C o u n t e r c h a r m e d "imp. & p. p. of Countercharm

Countercharming: C o u n t e r c h a r m i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Countercharm

Countercheck: C o u n t e r c h e c k "v. t. To oppose or check by some obstacle; to check by a return check.

Countercheck: C o u n t e r c h e c k "n. A check; a stop; a rebuke  or censure to check a reprover.

Countercheck: C o u n t e r c h e c k "n. Any force or device designed to restrain another restraining force; a check upon a check.

Counterchecked: C o u n t e r c h e c k e d "imp. & p. p. of Countercheck

Counterchecking: C o u n t e r c h e c k i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Countercheck

Counterclaim: C o u n t e r c l a i m "n. A claim made by a person as an offset to a claim made on him.

Countercurrent: C o u n t e r c u r r e n t "a. Running in an opposite direction.

Countercurrent: C o u n t e r c u r r e n t "n. A current running in an opposite direction to the main current.

Counterdraw: C o u n t e r d r a w "v. t. To copy  as a design or painting by tracing with a pencil on oiled paper or other transparent substance.

Counterdrawing: C o u n t e r d r a w i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Counterdraw

Counterdrawn: C o u n t e r d r a w n "p. p. of Counterdraw

Counterdrew: C o u n t e r d r e w "imp. of Counterdraw

Counterfaisance: C o u n t e r f a i s a n c e "n. See Counterfesance.

Counterfeit: C o u n t e r f e i t "adv. Representing by imitation or likeness; having a resemblance to something else; portrayed.

Counterfeit: C o u n t e r f e i t "adv. Fabricated in imitation of something else  with a view to defraud by passing the false copy for genuine or original; as counterfeit antiques; counterfeit coin.

Counterfeit: C o u n t e r f e i t "adv. Assuming the appearance of something; false; spurious; deceitful; hypocritical; as  a counterfeit philanthropist.

Counterfeit: C o u n t e r f e i t "n. That which resembles or is like another thing; a likeness; a portrait; a counterpart.

Counterfeit: C o u n t e r f e i t "n. That which is made in imitation of something  with a view to deceive by passing the false for the true; as the bank note was a counterfeit.

Counterfeit: C o u n t e r f e i t "n. One who pretends to be what he is not; one who personates another; an impostor; a cheat.

Counterfeit: C o u n t e r f e i t "v. t. To imitate  or put on a semblance of; to mimic; as to counterfeit the voice of another person.

Counterfeit: C o u n t e r f e i t "v. t. To imitate with a view to deceiving  by passing the copy for that which is original or genuine; to forge; as to counterfeit the signature of another coins notes etc.

Counterfeit: C o u n t e r f e i t "v. i. To carry on a deception; to dissemble; to feign; to pretend.

Counterfeit: C o u n t e r f e i t "v. i. To make counterfeits.

Counterfeited: C o u n t e r f e i t e d "imp. & p. p. of Counterfeit

Counterfeiter: C o u n t e r f e i t e r "n. One who counterfeits; one who copies or imitates; especially  one who copies or forges bank notes or coin; a forger.

Counterfeiter: C o u n t e r f e i t e r "n. One who assumes a false appearance or semblance; one who makes false pretenses.

Counterfeiting: C o u n t e r f e i t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Counterfeit

Counterfeitly: C o u n t e r f e i t l y "adv. By forgery; falsely.

Counterfesance: C o u n t e r f e s a n c e "a. The act of forging; forgery.

Counterfleury: C o u n t e r f l e u r y "a. Counterflory.

Counterflory: C o u n t e r f l o r y "a. Adorned with flowers (usually fleurs-de-lis) so divided that the tops appear on one side and the bottoms on the others; -- said of any ordinary.

Counterfoil: C o u n t e r f o i l "n. That part of a tally  formerly in the exchequer which was kept by an officer in that court the other called the stock being delivered to the person who had lent the king money on the account; -- called also counterstock.

Counterfoil: C o u n t e r f o i l "n. The part of a writing (as the stub of a bank check) in which are noted the main particulars contained in the corresponding part  which has been issued.

Counterforce: C o u n t e r f o r c e "n. An opposing force.

Counterfort: C o u n t e r f o r t "n. A kind of buttress of masonry to strengthen a revetment wall.

Counterfort: C o u n t e r f o r t "n. A spur or projection of a mountain.

Countergage: C o u n t e r g a g e "n. An adjustable gage  with double points for transferring measurements from one timber to another as the breadth of a mortise to the place where the tenon is to be made.

Counterguard: C o u n t e r g u a r d "n. A low outwork before a bastion or ravelin  consisting of two lines of rampart parallel to the faces of the bastion and protecting them from a breaching fire.

Counterirritant: C o u n t e r i r r i t a n t "n. Alt. of Counterirritation

Counterirritate: C o u n t e r i r r i t a t e "v. t. To produce counter irritation in; to treat with one morbid process for the purpose of curing another.

Counterirritation: C o u n t e r i r r i t a t i o n "n. See Counter irritant  etc. under Counter a.

Counterjumper: C o u n t e r j u m p e r "n. A salesman in a shop; a shopman; -- used contemptuously.

Counterman: C o u n t e r m a n "n. A man who attends at the counter of a shop to sell goods.

Countermand: C o u n t e r m a n d "v. t. To revoke (a former command); to cancel or rescind by giving an order contrary to one previously given; as  to countermand an order for goods.

Countermand: C o u n t e r m a n d "v. t. To prohibit; to forbid.

Countermand: C o u n t e r m a n d "v. t. To oppose; to revoke the command of.

Countermand: C o u n t e r m a n d "n. A contrary order; revocation of a former order or command.

Countermandable: C o u n t e r m a n d a b l e "a. Capable of being countermanded; revocable.

Countermanded: C o u n t e r m a n d e d "imp. & p. p. of Countermand

Countermanding: C o u n t e r m a n d i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Countermand

Countermarch: C o u n t e r m a r c h "v. i. To march back  or to march in reversed order.

Countermarch: C o u n t e r m a r c h "n. A marching back; retrocession.

Countermarch: C o u n t e r m a r c h "n. An evolution by which a body of troops change front or reverse the direction of march while retaining the same men in the front rank; also  a movement by which the rear rank becomes the front one either with or without changing the right to the left.

Countermarch: C o u n t e r m a r c h "n. A change of measures; alteration of conduct.

Countermarched: C o u n t e r m a r c h e d "imp. & p. p. of Countermarch

Countermarching: C o u n t e r m a r c h i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Countermarch

Countermark: C o u n t e r m a r k "n. A mark or token added to those already existing  in order to afford security or proof; as an additional or special mark put upon a package of goods belonging to several persons that it may not be opened except in the presence of all; a mark added to that of an artificer of gold or silver work by the Goldsmiths' Company of London to attest the standard quality of the gold or silver; a mark added to an ancient coin or medal to show either its change of value or that it was taken from an enemy.

Countermark: C o u n t e r m a r k "n. An artificial cavity made in the teeth of horses that have outgrown their natural mark  to disguise their age.

Countermark: C o u n t e r m a r k "v. t. To apply a countermark to; as  to countermark silverware; to countermark a horse's teeth.

Countermen: C o u n t e r m e n "pl. "of Counterman

Countermine: C o u n t e r m i n e "n. An underground gallery excavated to intercept and destroy the mining of an enemy.

Countermine: C o u n t e r m i n e "n. A stratagem or plot by which another sratagem or project is defeated.

Countermine: C o u n t e r m i n e "v. t. To oppose by means of a countermine; to intercept with a countermine.

Countermine: C o u n t e r m i n e "v. t. To frustrate or counteract by secret measures.

Countermine: C o u n t e r m i n e "v. i. To make a countermine or counterplot; to plot secretly.

Countermined: C o u n t e r m i n e d "imp. & p. p. of Countermine

Countermining: C o u n t e r m i n i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Countermine

Countermove: C o u n t e r m o v e "v. t. & i. To move in a contrary direction to.

Countermove: C o u n t e r m o v e " Alt. of Countermovement

Countermovement: C o u n t e r m o v e m e n t " A movement in opposition to another.

Countermure: C o u n t e r m u r e "n. A wall raised behind another  to supply its place when breached or destroyed. [R.] Cf. Contramure.

Countermure: C o u n t e r m u r e "v. t. To fortify with a wall behind another wall.

Countermured: C o u n t e r m u r e d "imp. & p. p. of Countermure

Countermuring: C o u n t e r m u r i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Countermure

Counternatural: C o u n t e r n a t u r a l "a. Contrary to nature.

Counterpane: C o u n t e r p a n e "n. A coverlet for a bed  -- originally stitched or woven in squares or figures.

Counterpane: C o u n t e r p a n e "n. A duplicate part or copy of an indenture  deed etc. corresponding with the original; -- now called counterpart.

Counterpart: C o u n t e r p a r t "n. A part corresponding to another part; anything which answers  or corresponds to another; a copy; a duplicate; a facsimile.

Counterpart: C o u n t e r p a r t "n. One of two corresponding copies of an instrument; a duplicate.

Counterpart: C o u n t e r p a r t "n. A person who closely resembles another.

Counterpart: C o u n t e r p a r t "n. A thing may be applied to another thing so as to fit perfectly  as a seal to its impression; hence a thing which is adapted to another thing or which supplements it; that which serves to complete or complement anything; hence a person or thing having qualities lacking in another; an opposite.

Counterpassant: C o u n t e r p a s s a n t "a. Passant in opposite directions; -- said of two animals.

Counterplead: C o u n t e r p l e a d "v. t. To plead the contrary of; to plead against; to deny.

Counterplot: C o u n t e r p l o t "v. t. To oppose  as another plot by plotting; to attempt to frustrate as a stratagem by stratagem.

Counterplot: C o u n t e r p l o t "n. A plot or artifice opposed to another.

Counterplotted: C o u n t e r p l o t t e d "imp. & p. p. of Counterplot

Counterplotting: C o u n t e r p l o t t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Counterplot

Counterpoint: C o u n t e r p o i n t "n. An opposite point

Counterpoint: C o u n t e r p o i n t "n. The setting of note against note in harmony; the adding of one or more parts to a given canto fermo or melody

Counterpoint: C o u n t e r p o i n t "n. The art of polyphony  or composite melody i. e. melody not single but moving attended by one or more related melodies.

Counterpoint: C o u n t e r p o i n t "n. Music in parts; part writing; harmony; polyphonic music. See Polyphony.

Counterpoint: C o u n t e r p o i n t "n. A coverlet; a cover for a bed  often stitched or broken into squares; a counterpane. See 1st Counterpane.

Counterpoise: C o u n t e r p o i s e "v. t. To act against with equal weight; to equal in weight; to balance the weight of; to counterbalance.

Counterpoise: C o u n t e r p o i s e "v. t. To act against with equal power; to balance.

Counterpoise: C o u n t e r p o i s e "n. A weight sufficient to balance another  as in the opposite scale of a balance; an equal weight.

Counterpoise: C o u n t e r p o i s e "n. An equal power or force acting in opposition; a force sufficient to balance another force.

Counterpoise: C o u n t e r p o i s e "n. The relation of two weights or forces which balance each other; equilibrium; equiponderance.

Counterpoised: C o u n t e r p o i s e d "imp. & p. p. of Counterpoise

Counterpoising: C o u n t e r p o i s i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Counterpoise

Counterpole: C o u n t e r p o l e "n. The exact opposite.

Counterponderate: C o u n t e r p o n d e r a t e "v. t. To equal in weight; to counterpoise; to equiponderate.

Counterprove: C o u n t e r p r o v e "v. t. To take a counter proof of  or a copy in reverse by taking an impression directly from the face of an original. See Counter proof under Counter.

Counterproved: C o u n t e r p r o v e d "imp. & p. p. of Counterprove

Counterproving: C o u n t e r p r o v i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Counterprove

Counterrolment: C o u n t e r r o l m e n t "n. A counter account. See Control.

Counterscale: C o u n t e r s c a l e "n. Counterbalance; balance  as of one scale against another.

Counterscarf: C o u n t e r s c a r f "n. The exterior slope or wall of the ditch; -- sometimes  the whole covered way beyond the ditch with its parapet and glacis; as the enemy have lodged themselves on the counterscarp.

Counterseal: C o u n t e r s e a l "v. t. To seal or ratify with another or others.

Countersealed: C o u n t e r s e a l e d "imp. & p. p. of Counterseal

Countersealing: C o u n t e r s e a l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Counterseal

Countersecure: C o u n t e r s e c u r e "v. t. To give additional security to or for.

Countershaft: C o u n t e r s h a f t "n. An intermediate shaft; esp.  one which receives motion from a line shaft in a factory and transmits it to a machine.

Countersign: C o u n t e r s i g n "v. t. To sign on the opposite side of (an instrument or writing); hence  to sign in addition to the signature of a principal or superior in order to attest the authenticity of a writing.

Countersign: C o u n t e r s i g n "a. The signature of a secretary or other officer to a writing signed by a principal or superior  to attest its authenticity.

Countersign: C o u n t e r s i g n "a. A private signal  word or phrase which must be given in order to pass a sentry; a watchword.

Countersigned: C o u n t e r s i g n e d "imp. & p. p. of Countersign

Countersigning: C o u n t e r s i g n i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Countersign

Countersink: C o u n t e r s i n k "v. t. To chamfer or form a depression around the top of (a hole in wood  metal etc.) for the reception of the head of a screw or bolt below the surface either wholly or in part; as to countersink a hole for a screw.

Countersink: C o u n t e r s i n k "v. t. To cause to sink even with or below the surface; as  to countersink a screw or bolt into woodwork.

Countersink: C o u n t e r s i n k "n. An enlargement of the upper part of a hole  forming a cavity or depression for receiving the head of a screw or bolt.

Countersink: C o u n t e r s i n k "n. A drill or cutting tool for countersinking holes.

Countersinking: C o u n t e r s i n k i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Countersink

Counterstand: C o u n t e r s t a n d "n. Resistance; opposition; a stand against.

Counterstep: C o u n t e r s t e p "n. A contrary method of procedure; opposite course of action.

Counterstock: C o u n t e r s t o c k "n. See Counterfoil.

Counterstroke: C o u n t e r s t r o k e "n. A stroke or blow in return.

Countersunk: C o u n t e r s u n k "imp. & p. p. of Countersink

Countersunk: C o u n t e r s u n k "p. p. & a. Chamfered at the top; -- said of a hole.

Countersunk: C o u n t e r s u n k "p. p. & a. Sunk into a chamfer; as  a countersunk bolt.

Countersunk: C o u n t e r s u n k "p. p. & a. Beveled on the lower side  so as to fit a chamfered countersink; as a countersunk nailhead.

Countersway: C o u n t e r s w a y "n. A swaying in a contrary direction; an opposing influence.

Counterterm: C o u n t e r t e r m "n. A term or word which is the opposite of  or antithesis to another; an antonym; -- the opposite of synonym; as foe is the counterterm of friend.

Countertime: C o u n t e r t i m e "n. The resistance of a horse  that interrupts his cadence and the measure of his manege occasioned by a bad horseman or the bad temper of the horse.

Countertime: C o u n t e r t i m e "n. Resistance; opposition.

Countertrippant: C o u n t e r t r i p p a n t "a. Trippant in opposite directions. See Trippant.

Countertripping: C o u n t e r t r i p p i n g "a. Same as Countertrippant.

Counterturn: C o u n t e r t u r n "n. The critical moment in a play  when contrary to expectation the action is embroiled in new difficulties.

Countervail: C o u n t e r v a i l "v. t. To act against with equal force  power or effect; to thwart or overcome by such action; to furnish an equivalent to or for; to counterbalance; to compensate.

Countervail: C o u n t e r v a i l "n. Power or value sufficient to obviate any effect; equal weight  strength or value; equivalent; compensation; requital.

Countervailed: C o u n t e r v a i l e d "imp. & p. p. of Countervail

Countervailing: C o u n t e r v a i l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Countervail

Countervallation: C o u n t e r v a l l a t i o n "n. See Contravallation.

Counterview: C o u n t e r v i e w "n. An opposite or opposing view; opposition; a posture in which two persons front each other.

Counterview: C o u n t e r v i e w "n. A position in which two dissimilar things illustrate each other by opposition; contrast.

Countervote: C o u n t e r v o t e "v. t. To vote in opposition to; to balance or overcome by voting; to outvote.

Counterwait: C o u n t e r w a i t "v. t. To wait or watch for; to be on guard against.

Counterweigh: C o u n t e r w e i g h "v. t. To weigh against; to counterbalance.

Counterwheel: C o u n t e r w h e e l "v. t. To cause to wheel or turn in an opposite direction.

Counterwork: C o u n t e r w o r k "v. t. To work in opposition to; to counteract.

Countess: C o u n t e s s "n. The wife of an earl in the British peerage  or of a count in the Continental nobility; also a lady possessed of the same dignity in her own right. See the Note under Count.

Countesses: C o u n t e s s e s "pl. "of Countess

Counties: C o u n t i e s "pl. "of County

Counting: C o u n t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Count

Countinghouse: C o u n t i n g h o u s e "v. Alt. of Countingroom

Countingroom: C o u n t i n g r o o m "v. The house or room in which a merchant  trader or manufacturer keeps his books and transacts business.

Countless: C o u n t l e s s "a. Incapable of being counted; not ascertainable; innumerable.

Countor: C o u n t o r "v. t. An advocate or professional pleader; one who counted for his client  that is orally pleaded his cause.

Countour: C o u n t o u r "n. Alt. of Countourhouse

Countourhouse: C o u n t o u r h o u s e "n. A merchant's office; a countinghouse.

Countre-: C o u n t r e - " Same as prefix Counter-.

Countreplete: C o u n t r e p l e t e "v. t. To counterplead.

Countretaille: C o u n t r e t a i l l e "n. A counter tally; correspondence (in sound).

Countries: C o u n t r i e s "pl. "of Country

Countrified: C o u n t r i f i e d "p. a. Having the appearance and manners of a rustic; rude.

Countrify: C o u n t r i f y "v. t. To give a rural appearance to; to cause to appear rustic.

Country: C o u n t r y "adv. A tract of land; a region; the territory of an independent nation; (as distinguished from any other region  and with a personal pronoun) the region of one's birth permanent residence or citizenship.

Country: C o u n t r y "adv. Rural regions  as opposed to a city or town.

Country: C o u n t r y "adv. The inhabitants or people of a state or a region; the populace; the public. Hence: (a) One's constituents. (b) The whole body of the electors of state; as  to dissolve Parliament and appeal to the country.

Country: C o u n t r y "adv. A jury  as representing the citizens of a country.

Country: C o u n t r y "adv. The inhabitants of the district from which a jury is drawn.

Country: C o u n t r y "adv. The rock through which a vein runs.

Country: C o u n t r y "a. Pertaining to the regions remote from a city; rural; rustic; as  a country life; a country town; the country party as opposed to city.

Country: C o u n t r y "a. Destitute of refinement; rude; unpolished; rustic; not urbane; as  country manners.

Country: C o u n t r y "a. Pertaining  or peculiar to one's own country.

Country seat: C o u n t r y   s e a t " A dwelling in the country  used as a place of retirement from the city.

Country-base: C o u n t r y - b a s e "n. Same as Prison base.

Country-dance: C o u n t r y - d a n c e "n. See Contradance.

Countryman: C o u n t r y m a n "n. An inhabitant or native of a region.

Countryman: C o u n t r y m a n "n. One born in the same country with another; a compatriot; -- used with a possessive pronoun.

Countryman: C o u n t r y m a n "n. One who dwells in the country  as distinguished from a townsman or an inhabitant of a city; a rustic; a husbandman or farmer.

Countrymen: C o u n t r y m e n "pl. "of Countryman

Countryside: C o u n t r y s i d e "n. A particular rural district; a country neighborhood.

Countrywoman: C o u n t r y w o m a n "n. A woman born  or dwelling in the country as opposed to the city; a woman born or dwelling in the same country with another native or inhabitant.

Countrywomen: C o u n t r y w o m e n "pl. "of Countrywoman

Counttenance: C o u n t t e n a n c e "n. Appearance or expression of the face; look; aspect; mien.

Counttenance: C o u n t t e n a n c e "n. The face; the features.

Counttenance: C o u n t t e n a n c e "n. Approving or encouraging aspect of face; hence  favor good will support; aid; encouragement.

Counttenance: C o u n t t e n a n c e "n. Superficial appearance; show; pretense.

County: C o u n t y "n. An earldom; the domain of a count or earl.

County: C o u n t y "n. A circuit or particular portion of a state or kingdom  separated from the rest of the territory for certain purposes in the administration of justice and public affairs; -- called also a shire. See Shire.

County: C o u n t y "n. A count; an earl or lord.

Coup: C o u p "n. A sudden stroke; an unexpected device or stratagem; -- a term used in various ways to convey the idea of promptness and force.

Coupable: C o u p a b l e "a. Culpable.

Coupe: C o u p e "n. The front compartment of a French diligence; also  the front compartment (usually for three persons) of a car or carriage on British railways.

Coupe: C o u p e "n. A four-wheeled close carriage for two persons inside  with an outside seat for the driver; -- so called because giving the appearance of a larger carriage cut off.

Coupe-gorge: C o u p e - g o r g e "n. Any position giving the enemy such advantage that the troops occupying it must either surrender or be cut to pieces.

Couped: C o u p e d "a. Cut off smoothly  as distinguished from erased; -- used especially for the head or limb of an animal. See Erased.

Coupee: C o u p e e "n. A motion in dancing  when one leg is a little bent and raised from the floor and with the other a forward motion is made.

Couple: C o u p l e "a. That which joins or links two things together; a bond or tie; a coupler.

Couple: C o u p l e "a. Two of the same kind connected or considered together; a pair; a brace.

Couple: C o u p l e "a. A male and female associated together; esp.  a man and woman who are married or betrothed.

Couple: C o u p l e "a. See Couple-close.

Couple: C o u p l e "a. One of the pairs of plates of two metals which compose a voltaic battery; -- called a voltaic couple or galvanic couple.

Couple: C o u p l e "a. Two rotations  movements etc. which are equal in amount but opposite in direction and acting along parallel lines or around parallel axes.

Couple: C o u p l e "v. To link or tie  as one thing to another; to connect or fasten together; to join.

Couple: C o u p l e "v. To join in wedlock; to marry.

Couple: C o u p l e "v. i. To come together as male and female; to copulate.

Couple-beggar: C o u p l e - b e g g a r "n. One who makes it his business to marry beggars to each other.

Couple-close: C o u p l e - c l o s e "n. A diminutive of the chevron  containing one fourth of its surface. Couple-closes are generally borne one on each side of a chevron and the blazoning may then be either a chevron between two couple-closes or chevron cottised.

Couple-close: C o u p l e - c l o s e "n. A pair of rafters framed together with a tie fixed at their feet  or with a collar beam.

Couple-closes: C o u p l e - c l o s e s "pl. "of Couple-close

Coupled: C o u p l e d "imp. & p. p. of Couple

Couplement: C o u p l e m e n t "n. Union; combination; a coupling; a pair.

Coupler: C o u p l e r "n. One who couples; that which couples  as a link ring or shackle to connect cars.

Couplet: C o u p l e t "n. Two taken together; a pair or couple; especially two lines of verse that rhyme with each other.

Coupling: C o u p l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Couple

Coupling: C o u p l i n g "n. The act of bringing or coming together; connection; sexual union.

Coupling: C o u p l i n g "n. A device or contrivance which serves to couple or connect adjacent parts or objects; as  a belt coupling which connects the ends of a belt; a car coupling which connects the cars in a train; a shaft coupling which connects the ends of shafts.

Coupon: C o u p o n "n. A certificate of interest due  printed at the bottom of transferable bonds (state railroad etc.) given for a term of years designed to be cut off and presented for payment when the interest is due; an interest warrant.

Coupon: C o u p o n "n. A section of a ticket  showing the holder to be entitled to some specified accomodation or service as to a passage over a designated line of travel a particular seat in a theater or the like.

Coupure: C o u p u r e "n. A passage cut through the glacis to facilitate sallies by the besieged.

Courage: C o u r a g e "n. The heart; spirit; temper; disposition.

Courage: C o u r a g e "n. Heart; inclination; desire; will.

Courage: C o u r a g e "n. That quality of mind which enables one to encounter danger and difficulties with firmness  or without fear or fainting of heart; valor; boldness; resolution.

Courageous: C o u r a g e o u s "a. Possessing  or characterized by courage; brave; bold.

Courageously: C o u r a g e o u s l y "adv. In a courageous manner.

Courageousness: C o u r a g e o u s n e s s "n. The quality of being courageous; courage.

Courant: C o u r a n t "a. Represented as running; -- said of a beast borne in a coat of arms.

Courant: C o u r a n t "p. pr. A piece of music in triple time; also  a lively dance; a coranto.

Courant: C o u r a n t "p. pr. A circulating gazette of news; a newspaper.

Couranto: C o u r a n t o "n. A sprightly dance; a coranto; a courant.

Courap: C o u r a p "n. A skin disease  common in India in which there is perpetual itching and eruption esp. of the groin breast armpits and face.

Courb: C o u r b "a. Curved; rounded.

Courb: C o u r b "v. i. To bend; to stop; to bow.

Courbaril: C o u r b a r i l "n. See Anime  n.

Courche: C o u r c h e "n. A square piece of linen used formerly by women instead of a cap; a kerchief.

Courier: C o u r i e r "n. A messenger sent with haste to convey letters or dispatches  usually on public business.

Courier: C o u r i e r "n. An attendant on travelers  whose business it is to make arrangements for their convenience at hotels and on the way.

Courlan: C o u r l a n "n. A South American bird  of the genus Aramus allied to the rails.

Course: C o u r s e "n. The act of moving from one point to another; progress; passage.

Course: C o u r s e "n. The ground or path traversed; track; way.

Course: C o u r s e "n. Motion  considered as to its general or resultant direction or to its goal; line progress or advance.

Course: C o u r s e "n. Progress from point to point without change of direction; any part of a progress from one place to another  which is in a straight line or on one direction; as a ship in a long voyage makes many courses; a course measured by a surveyor between two stations; also a progress without interruption or rest; a heat; as one course of a race.

Course: C o u r s e "n. Motion considered with reference to manner; or derly progress; procedure in a certain line of thought or action; as  the course of an argument.

Course: C o u r s e "n. Customary or established sequence of events; recurrence of events according to natural laws.

Course: C o u r s e "n. Method of procedure; manner or way of conducting; conduct; behavior.

Course: C o u r s e "n. A series of motions or acts arranged in order; a succession of acts or practices connectedly followed; as  a course of medicine; a course of lectures on chemistry.

Course: C o u r s e "n. The succession of one to another in office or duty; order; turn.

Course: C o u r s e "n. That part of a meal served at one time  with its accompaniments.

Course: C o u r s e "n. A continuous level range of brick or stones of the same height throughout the face or faces of a building.

Course: C o u r s e "n. The lowest sail on any mast of a square-rigged vessel; as  the fore course main course etc.

Course: C o u r s e "n. The menses.

Course: C o u r s e "v. t. To run  hunt or chase after; to follow hard upon; to pursue.

Course: C o u r s e "v. t. To cause to chase after or pursue game; as  to course greyhounds after deer.

Course: C o u r s e "v. t. To run through or over.

Course: C o u r s e "v. i. To run as in a race  or in hunting; to pursue the sport of coursing; as the sportsmen coursed over the flats of Lancashire.

Course: C o u r s e "v. i. To move with speed; to race; as  the blood courses through the veins.

Coursed: C o u r s e d "imp. & p. p. of Course

Coursed: C o u r s e d "a. Hunted; as  a coursed hare.

Coursed: C o u r s e d "a. Arranged in courses; as  coursed masonry.

Courser: C o u r s e r "n. One who courses or hunts.

Courser: C o u r s e r "n. A swift or spirited horse; a racer or a war horse; a charger.

Courser: C o u r s e r "n. A grallatorial bird of Europe (Cursorius cursor)  remarkable for its speed in running. Sometimes in a wider sense applied to running birds of the Ostrich family.

Coursey: C o u r s e y "n. A space in the galley; a part of the hatches.

Coursing: C o u r s i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Course

Coursing: C o u r s i n g "n. The pursuit or running game with dogs that follow by sight instead of by scent.

Court: C o u r t "n. An inclosed space; a courtyard; an uncovered area shut in by the walls of a building  or by different building; also a space opening from a street and nearly surrounded by houses; a blind alley.

Court: C o u r t "n. The residence of a sovereign  prince nobleman or ether dignitary; a palace.

Court: C o u r t "n. The collective body of persons composing the retinue of a sovereign or person high in authority; all the surroundings of a sovereign in his regal state.

Court: C o u r t "n. Any formal assembling of the retinue of a sovereign; as  to hold a court.

Court: C o u r t "n. Attention directed to a person in power; conduct or address designed to gain favor; courtliness of manners; civility; compliment; flattery.

Court: C o u r t "n. The hall  chamber or place where justice is administered.

Court: C o u r t "n. The persons officially assembled under authority of law  at the appropriate time and place for the administration of justice; an official assembly legally met together for the transaction of judicial business; a judge or judges sitting for the hearing or trial of causes.

Court: C o u r t "n. A tribunal established for the administration of justice.

Court: C o u r t "n. The judge or judges; as distinguished from the counsel or jury  or both.

Court: C o u r t "n. The session of a judicial assembly.

Court: C o u r t "n. Any jurisdiction  civil military or ecclesiastical.

Court: C o u r t "n. A place arranged for playing the game of tennis; also  one of the divisions of a tennis court.

Court: C o u r t "v. t. To endeavor to gain the favor of by attention or flattery; to try to ingratiate one's self with.

Court: C o u r t "v. t. To endeavor to gain the affections of; to seek in marriage; to woo.

Court: C o u r t "v. t. To attempt to gain; to solicit; to seek.

Court: C o u r t "v. t. To invite by attractions; to allure; to attract.

Court: C o u r t "v. i. To play the lover; to woo; as  to go courting.

Court tennis: C o u r t   t e n n i s " See under Tennis.

Court-baron: C o u r t - b a r o n "n. An inferior court of civil jurisdiction  attached to a manor and held by the steward; a baron's court; -- now fallen into disuse.

Court-craft: C o u r t - c r a f t "n. The artifices  intrigues and plottings at courts.

Court-cupboard: C o u r t - c u p b o a r d "n. A movable sideboard or buffet  on which plate and other articles of luxury were displayed on special ocasions.

Court-leet: C o u r t - l e e t "n. A court of record held once a year  in a particular hundred lordship or manor before the steward of the leet.

Court-martial: C o u r t - m a r t i a l "n. A court consisting of military or naval officers  for the trial of one belonging to the army or navy or of offenses against military or naval law.

Court-martial: C o u r t - m a r t i a l "v. t. To subject to trial by a court-martial.

Court-martialed: C o u r t - m a r t i a l e d "imp. & p. p. of Court-martial

Court-martialing: C o u r t - m a r t i a l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Court-martial

Court-plaster: C o u r t - p l a s t e r "n. Sticking plaster made by coating taffeta or silk on one side with some adhesive substance  commonly a mixture of isinglass and glycerin.

Courtbred: C o u r t b r e d "a. Bred  or educated at court; polished; courtly.

Courted: C o u r t e d "imp. & p. p. of Court

Courtehouse: C o u r t e h o u s e "n. A house in which established courts are held  or a house appropriated to courts and public meetings.

Courtehouse: C o u r t e h o u s e "n. A county town; -- so called in Virginia and some others of the Southern States.

Courteous: C o u r t e o u s "a. Of courtlike manners; pertaining to  or expressive of courtesy; characterized by courtesy; civil; obliging; well bred; polite; affable; complaisant.

Courteously: C o u r t e o u s l y "adv. In a courteous manner.

Courteousness: C o u r t e o u s n e s s "n. The quality of being courteous; politeness; courtesy.

Courtepy: C o u r t e p y "n. A short coat of coarse cloth.

Courter: C o u r t e r "n. One who courts; one who plays the lover  or who solicits in marriage; one who flatters and cajoles.

Courtesan: C o u r t e s a n "n. A woman who prostitutes herself for hire; a prostitute; a harlot.

Courtesanship: C o u r t e s a n s h i p "n. Harlotry.

Courtesied: C o u r t e s i e d "imp. & p. p. of Courtesy

Courtesies: C o u r t e s i e s "pl. "of Courtesy

Courtesy: C o u r t e s y "n. Politeness; civility; urbanity; courtliness.

Courtesy: C o u r t e s y "n. An act of civility or respect; an act of kindness or favor performed with politeness.

Courtesy: C o u r t e s y "n. Favor or indulgence  as distinguished from right; as a title given one by courtesy.

Courtesy: C o u r t e s y "n. An act of civility  respect or reverence made by women consisting of a slight depression or dropping of the body with bending of the knees.

Courtesy: C o u r t e s y "v. i. To make a respectful salutation or movement of respect; esp. (with reference to women)  to bow the body slightly with bending of the knes.

Courtesy: C o u r t e s y "v. t. To treat with civility.

Courtesying: C o u r t e s y i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Courtesy

Courtier: C o u r t i e r "n. One who is in attendance at the court of a prince; one who has an appointment at court.

Courtier: C o u r t i e r "n. One who courts or solicits favor; one who flatters.

Courtiery: C o u r t i e r y "n. The manners of a courtier; courtliness.

Courting: C o u r t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Court

Courtlike: C o u r t l i k e "a. After the manner of a court; elegant; polite; courtly.

Courtliness: C o u r t l i n e s s "n. The quality of being courtly; elegance or dignity of manners.

Courtling: C o u r t l i n g "n. A sycophantic courtier.

Courtly: C o u r t l y "a. Relating or belonging to a court.

Courtly: C o u r t l y "a. Elegant; polite; courtlike; flattering.

Courtly: C o u r t l y "a. Disposed to favor the great; favoring the policy or party of the court; obsequious.

Courtly: C o u r t l y "adv. In the manner of courts; politely; gracefully; elegantly.

Courts-martial: C o u r t s - m a r t i a l "pl. "of Court-martial

Courtship: C o u r t s h i p "n. The act of paying court  with the intent to solicit a favor.

Courtship: C o u r t s h i p "n. The act of wooing in love; solicitation of woman to marriage.

Courtship: C o u r t s h i p "n. Courtliness; elegance of manners; courtesy.

Courtship: C o u r t s h i p "n. Court policy; the character of a courtier; artifice of a court; court-craft; finesse.

Courtyard: C o u r t y a r d "n. A court or inclosure attached to a house.

Couscous: C o u s c o u s "n. A kind of food used by the natives of Western Africa  made of millet flour with flesh and leaves of the baobab; -- called also lalo.

Couscousou: C o u s c o u s o u "n. A favorite dish in Barbary. See Couscous.

Cousin: C o u s i n "n. One collaterally related more remotely than a brother or sister; especially  the son or daughter of an uncle or aunt.

Cousin: C o u s i n "n. A title formerly given by a king to a nobleman  particularly to those of the council. In English writs etc. issued by the crown it signifies any earl.

Cousin: C o u s i n "n. Allied; akin.

Cousin-german: C o u s i n - g e r m a n "n. A first cousin. See Note under Cousin  1.

Cousinage: C o u s i n a g e "n. Relationship; kinship.

Cousinhood: C o u s i n h o o d "n. The state or condition of a cousin; also  the collective body of cousins; kinsfolk.

Cousinly: C o u s i n l y "a. Like or becoming a cousin.

Cousinry: C o u s i n r y "n. A body or collection of cousins; the whole number of persons who stand in the relation of cousins to a given person or persons.

Cousinship: C o u s i n s h i p "n. The relationship of cousins; state of being cousins; cousinhood.

Coussinet: C o u s s i n e t "n. A stone placed on the impost of a pier for receiving the first stone of an arch.

Coussinet: C o u s s i n e t "n. That part of the Ionic capital between the abacus and quarter round  which forms the volute.

Couteau: C o u t e a u "n. A knife; a dagger.

Couth: C o u t h "imp. & p. p. Could; was able; knew or known; understood.

Couvade: C o u v a d e "n. A custom  among certain barbarous tribes that when a woman gives birth to a child her husband takes to his bed as if ill.

Covariant: C o v a r i a n t "n. A function involving the coefficients and the variables of a quantic  and such that when the quantic is lineally transformed the same function of the new variables and coefficients shall be equal to the old function multiplied by a factor. An invariant is a like function involving only the coefficients of the quantic.

Cove: C o v e "n. A retired nook; especially  a small sheltered inlet creek or bay; a recess in the shore.

Cove: C o v e "n. A strip of prairie extending into woodland; also  a recess in the side of a mountain.

Cove: C o v e "n. A concave molding.

Cove: C o v e "n. A member  whose section is a concave curve used especially with regard to an inner roof or ceiling as around a skylight.

Cove: C o v e "v. t. To arch over; to build in a hollow concave form; to make in the form of a cove.

Cove: C o v e "v. t. To brood  cover over or sit over as birds their eggs.

Cove: C o v e "n. A boy or man of any age or station.

Coved: C o v e d "imp. & p. p. of Cove

Covelline: C o v e l l i n e "n. Alt. of Covellite

Covellite: C o v e l l i t e "n. A native sulphide of copper  occuring in masses of a dark blue color; -- hence called indigo copper.

Covenable: C o v e n a b l e "a. Fit; proper; suitable.

Covenably: C o v e n a b l y "adv. Fitly; suitably.

Covenant: C o v e n a n t "n. A mutual agreement of two or more persons or parties  or one of the stipulations in such an agreement.

Covenant: C o v e n a n t "n. An agreement made by the Scottish Parliament in 1638  and by the English Parliament in 1643 to preserve the reformed religion in Scotland and to extirpate popery and prelacy; -- usually called the Solemn League and Covenant.

Covenant: C o v e n a n t "n. The promises of God as revealed in the Scriptures  conditioned on certain terms on the part of man as obedience repentance faith etc.

Covenant: C o v e n a n t "n. A solemn compact between members of a church to maintain its faith  discipline etc.

Covenant: C o v e n a n t "n. An undertaking  on sufficient consideration in writing and under seal to do or to refrain from some act or thing; a contract; a stipulation; also the document or writing containing the terms of agreement.

Covenant: C o v e n a n t "n. A form of action for the violation of a promise or contract under seal.

Covenant: C o v e n a n t "v. i. To agree (with); to enter into a formal agreement; to bind one's self by contract; to make a stipulation.

Covenant: C o v e n a n t "v. t. To grant or promise by covenant.

Covenanted: C o v e n a n t e d "imp. & p. p. of Covenant

Covenantee: C o v e n a n t e e "n. The person in whose favor a covenant is made.

Covenanter: C o v e n a n t e r "n. One who makes a covenant.

Covenanter: C o v e n a n t e r "n. One who subscribed and defended the Solemn League and Covenant. See Covenant.

Covenanting: C o v e n a n t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Covenant

Covenanting: C o v e n a n t i n g "a. Belonging to a covenant. Specifically  belonging to the Scotch Covenanters.

Covenantor: C o v e n a n t o r "n. The party who makes a covenant.

Covenous: C o v e n o u s "a. See Covinous  and Covin.

Covent: C o v e n t "n. A convent or monastery.

Coventry: C o v e n t r y "n. A town in the county of Warwick  England.

Cover: C o v e r "v. t. To overspread the surface of (one thing) with another; as  to cover wood with paint or lacquer; to cover a table with a cloth.

Cover: C o v e r "v. t. To envelop; to clothe  as with a mantle or cloak.

Cover: C o v e r "v. t. To invest (one's self with something); to bring upon (one's self); as  he covered himself with glory.

Cover: C o v e r "v. t. To hide sight; to conceal; to cloak; as  the enemy were covered from our sight by the woods.

Cover: C o v e r "v. t. To brood or sit on; to incubate.

Cover: C o v e r "v. t. To shelter  as from evil or danger; to protect; to defend; as the cavalry covered the retreat.

Cover: C o v e r "v. t. To remove from remembrance; to put away; to remit.

Cover: C o v e r "v. t. To extend over; to be sufficient for; to comprehend  include or embrace; to account for or solve; to counterbalance; as a mortgage which fully covers a sum loaned on it; a law which covers all possible cases of a crime; receipts than do not cover expenses.

Cover: C o v e r "v. t. To put the usual covering or headdress on.

Cover: C o v e r "v. t. To copulate with (a female); to serve; as  a horse covers a mare; -- said of the male.

Cover: C o v e r "n. Anything which is laid  set or spread upon about or over another thing; an envelope; a lid; as the cover of a book.

Cover: C o v e r "n. Anything which veils or conceals; a screen; disguise; a cloak.

Cover: C o v e r "n. Shelter; protection; as  the troops fought under cover of the batteries; the woods afforded a good cover.

Cover: C o v e r "n. The woods  underbrush etc. which shelter and conceal game; covert; as to beat a cover; to ride to cover.

Cover: C o v e r "n. The lap of a slide valve.

Cover: C o v e r "n. A tablecloth  and the other table furniture; esp. the table furniture for the use of one person at a meal; as covers were laid for fifty guests.

Cover: C o v e r "v. i. To spread a table for a meal; to prepare a banquet.

Cover-point: C o v e r - p o i n t "n. The fielder in the games of cricket and lacrosse who supports point.

Cover-shame: C o v e r - s h a m e "n. Something used to conceal infamy.

Coverchief: C o v e r c h i e f "n. A covering for the head.

Covercle: C o v e r c l e "n. A small cover; a lid.

Covered: C o v e r e d "imp. & p. p. of Cover

Covered: C o v e r e d "a. Under cover; screened; sheltered; not exposed; hidden.

Covering: C o v e r i n g "n. Anything which covers or conceals  as a roof a screen a wrapper clothing etc.

Coverlet: C o v e r l e t "n. The uppermost cover of a bed or of any piece of furniture.

Coverlid: C o v e r l i d "n. A coverlet.

Coversed sine: C o v e r s e d   s i n e " The versed sine of the complement of an arc or angle. See Illust. of Functions.

Covert: C o v e r t "v. t. Covered over; private; hid; secret; disguised.

Covert: C o v e r t "v. t. Sheltered; not open or exposed; retired; protected; as  a covert nook.

Covert: C o v e r t "v. t. Under cover  authority or protection; as a feme covert a married woman who is considered as being under the protection and control of her husband.

Covert: C o v e r t "a. A place that covers and protects; a shelter; a defense.

Covert: C o v e r t "a. One of the special feathers covering the bases of the quills of the wings and tail of a bird. See Illust. of Bird.

Covert baron: C o v e r t   b a r o n " Under the protection of a husband; married.

Covertly: C o v e r t l y "adv. Secretly; in private; insidiously.

Covertness: C o v e r t n e s s "n. Secrecy; privacy.

Coverture: C o v e r t u r e "n. Covering; shelter; defense; hiding.

Coverture: C o v e r t u r e "n. The condition of a woman during marriage  because she is considered under the cover influence power and protection of her husband and therefore called a feme covert or femme couverte.

Covet: C o v e t "v. t. To wish for with eagerness; to desire possession of; -- used in a good sense.

Covet: C o v e t "v. t. To long for inordinately or unlawfully; to hanker after (something forbidden).

Covet: C o v e t "v. i. To have or indulge inordinate desire.

Covetable: C o v e t a b l e "a. That may be coveted; desirable.

Coveter: C o v e t e r "n. One who covets.

Coveting: C o v e t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Covet

Covetise: C o v e t i s e "v. t. Avarice.

Covetiveness: C o v e t i v e n e s s "n. Acquisitiveness.

Covetous: C o v e t o u s "v. t. Very desirous; eager to obtain; -- used in a good sense.

Covetous: C o v e t o u s "v. t. Inordinately desirous; excessively eager to obtain and possess (esp. money); avaricious; -- in a bad sense.

Covetously: C o v e t o u s l y "adv. In a covetous manner.

Covetousness: C o v e t o u s n e s s "n. Strong desire.

Covetousness: C o v e t o u s n e s s "n. A strong or inordinate desire of obtaining and possessing some supposed good; excessive desire for riches or money; -- in a bad sense.

Covey: C o v e y "n. A brood or hatch of birds; an old bird with her brood of young; hence  a small flock or number of birds together; -- said of game; as a covey of partridges.

Covey: C o v e y "n. A company; a bevy; as  a covey of girls.

Covey: C o v e y "v. i. To brood; to incubate.

Covey: C o v e y "n. A pantry.

Cow: C o w "n. A chimney cap; a cowl

Cow: C o w "n. The mature female of bovine animals.

Cow: C o w "n. The female of certain large mammals  as whales seals etc.

Cow: C o w "v. t. To depress with fear; to daunt the spirits or courage of; to overawe.

Cow: C o w "n. A wedge  or brake to check the motion of a machine or car; a chock.

Cow parsley: C o w   p a r s l e y " An umbelliferous plant of the genus Chaerophyllum (C. temulum and C. sylvestre).

Cow parsnip: C o w   p a r s n i p " A coarse umbelliferous weed of the genus Heracleum (H. sphondylium in England  and H. lanatum in America).

Cow tree: C o w   t r e e " A tree (Galactodendron utile or Brosimum Galactodendron) of South America  which yields on incision a nourishing fluid resembling milk.

Cow-pilot: C o w - p i l o t "n. A handsomely banded  coral-reef fish of Florida and the West Indies (Pomacentrus saxatilis); -- called also mojarra.

Cow's lungwort: C o w ' s   l u n g w o r t " Mullein.

Cowage: C o w a g e "n. See Cowhage.

Cowan: C o w a n "n. One who works as a mason without having served a regular apprenticeship.

Coward: C o w a r d "a. Borne in the escutcheon with his tail doubled between his legs; -- said of a lion.

Coward: C o w a r d "a. Destitute of courage; timid; cowardly.

Coward: C o w a r d "a. Belonging to a coward; proceeding from  or expressive of base fear or timidity.

Coward: C o w a r d "n. A person who lacks courage; a timid or pusillanimous person; a poltroon.

Coward: C o w a r d "v. t. To make timorous; to frighten.

Cowardice: C o w a r d i c e "n. Want of courage to face danger; extreme timidity; pusillanimity; base fear of danger or hurt; lack of spirit.

Cowardie: C o w a r d i e "n. Cowardice.

Cowardish: C o w a r d i s h "a. Cowardly.

Cowardize: C o w a r d i z e "v. t. "To render cowardly

Cowardliness: C o w a r d l i n e s s "n. Cowardice.

Cowardly: C o w a r d l y "a. Wanting courage; basely or weakly timid or fearful; pusillanimous; spiritless.

Cowardly: C o w a r d l y "a. Proceeding from fear of danger or other consequences; befitting a coward; dastardly; base; as  cowardly malignity.

Cowardly: C o w a r d l y "adv. In the manner of a coward.

Cowardship: C o w a r d s h i p "n. Cowardice.

Cowbane: C o w b a n e "n. A poisonous umbelliferous plant; in England  the Cicuta virosa; in the United States the Cicuta maculata and the Archemora rigida. See Water hemlock.

Cowberries: C o w b e r r i e s "pl. "of Cowberry

Cowberry: C o w b e r r y "n. A species of Vaccinium (V. Vitis-idaea)  which bears acid red berries which are sometimes used in cookery; -- locally called mountain cranberry.

Cowbird: C o w b i r d "n. The cow blackbird (Molothrus ater)  an American starling. Like the European cuckoo it builds no nest but lays its eggs in the nests of other birds; -- so called because frequently associated with cattle.

Cowblakes: C o w b l a k e s "n. pl. Dried cow dung used as fuel.

Cowboy: C o w b o y "n. A cattle herder; a drover; specifically  one of an adventurous class of herders and drovers on the plains of the Western and Southwestern United States.

Cowboy: C o w b o y "n. One of the marauders who  in the Revolutionary War infested the neutral ground between the American and British lines and committed depredations on the Americans.

Cowcatxjer: C o w c a t x j e r "n. A strong inclined frame  usually of wrought-iron bars in front of a locomotive engine for catching or throwing off obstructions on a railway as cattle; the pilot.

Cowdie: C o w d i e "n. See Kauri.

Cowed: C o w e d "imp. & p. p. of Cow

Cower: C o w e r "v. i. To stoop by bending the knees; to crouch; to squat; hence  to quail; to sink through fear.

Cowfish: C o w f i s h "n. The grampus.

Cowfish: C o w f i s h "n. A California dolphin (Tursiops Gillii).

Cowfish: C o w f i s h "n. A marine plectognath fish (Ostracoin quadricorne  and allied species) having two projections like horns in front; -- called also cuckold coffer fish trunkfish.

Cowhage: C o w h a g e "n. A leguminous climbing plant of the genus Mucuna  having crooked pods covered with sharp hairs which stick to the fingers causing intolerable itching. The spiculae are sometimes used in medicine as a mechanical vermifuge.

Cowhearted: C o w h e a r t e d "a. Cowardly.

Cowherd: C o w h e r d "n. One whose occupation is to tend cows.

Cowhide: C o w h i d e "n. The hide of a cow.

Cowhide: C o w h i d e "n. Leather made of the hide of a cow.

Cowhide: C o w h i d e "n. A coarse whip made of untanned leather.

Cowhide: C o w h i d e "v. t. To flog with a cowhide.

Cowish: C o w i s h "v. t. Timorous; fearful; cowardly.

Cowish: C o w i s h "n. An umbelliferous plant (Peucedanum Cous) with edible tuberous roots  found in Oregon.

Cowitch: C o w i t c h "n. See Cowhage.

Cowl: C o w l "n. A monk's hood; -- usually attached to the gown. The name was also applied to the hood and garment together.

Cowl: C o w l "n. A cowl-shaped cap  commonly turning with the wind used to improve the draft of a chimney ventilating shaft etc.

Cowl: C o w l "n. A wire cap for the smokestack of a locomotive.

Cowl: C o w l "n. A vessel carried on a pole between two persons  for conveyance of water.

Cowled: C o w l e d "a. Wearing a cowl; hooded; as  a cowled monk.

Cowleech: C o w l e e c h "n. One who heals diseases of cows; a cow doctor.

Cowleeching: C o w l e e c h i n g "n. Healing the distemper of cows.

Cowlick: C o w l i c k "n. A tuft of hair turned up or awry (usually over the forehead)  as if licked by a cow.

Cowlike: C o w l i k e "a. Resembling a cow.

Cowlstaff: C o w l s t a f f "n. A staff or pole on which a vessel is supported between two persons.

Coworker: C o w o r k e r "n. One who works with another; a co/perator.

Cowpea: C o w p e a "n. The seed of one or more leguminous plants of the genus Dolichos; also  the plant itself. Many varieties are cultivated in the southern part of the United States.

Cowper's glands: C o w p e r ' s   g l a n d s " Two small glands discharging into the male urethra.

Cowpock: C o w p o c k "n. See Cowpox.

Cowpox: C o w p o x "n. A pustular eruptive disease of the cow  which when communicated to the human system as by vaccination protects from the smallpox; vaccinia; -- called also kinepox cowpock and kinepock.

Cowquake: C o w q u a k e "n. A genus of plants (Briza); quaking grass.

Cows: C o w s "pl. "of Cow

Cowslip: C o w s l i p "n. A common flower in England (Primula veris) having yellow blossoms and appearing in early spring. It is often cultivated in the United States.

Cowslip: C o w s l i p "n. In the United States  the marsh marigold (Caltha palustris) appearing in wet places in early spring and often used as a pot herb. It is nearer to a buttercup than to a true cowslip. See Illust. of Marsh marigold.

Cowslipped: C o w s l i p p e d "a. Adorned with cowslips.

Cowwheat: C o w w h e a t "n. A weed of the genus Melampyrum  with black seeds found on European wheatfields.

Coxcomb: C o x c o m b "n. The top of the head  or the head itself

Coyote: C o y o t e "n. A carnivorous animal (Canis latrans)  allied to the dog found in the western part of North America; -- called also prairie wolf. Its voice is a snapping bark followed by a prolonged shrill howl.

Coypu: C o y p u "n. A South American rodent (Myopotamus coypus)  allied to the beaver. It produces a valuable fur called nutria.

Coystrel: C o y s t r e l "n. Same as Coistril.

Coz: C o z "n. A contraction of cousin.

Cr/che: C r / c h e "n. A public nursery  where the young children of poor women are cared for during the day while their mothers are at work.

Crab: C r a b "n. One of the brachyuran Crustacea. They are mostly marine  and usually have a broad short body covered with a strong shell or carapace. The abdomen is small and curled up beneath the body.

Crab: C r a b "n. The zodiacal constellation Cancer.

Crab: C r a b "a. A crab apple; -- so named from its harsh taste.

Crab: C r a b "a. A cudgel made of the wood of the crab tree; a crabstick.

Crab: C r a b "a. A movable winch or windlass with powerful gearing  used with derricks etc.

Crab: C r a b "a. A form of windlass  or geared capstan for hauling ships into dock etc.

Crab: C r a b "a. A machine used in ropewalks to stretch the yarn.

Crab: C r a b "a. A claw for anchoring a portable machine.

Crab: C r a b "v. t. To make sour or morose; to embitter.

Crab: C r a b "v. t. To beat with a crabstick.

Crab: C r a b "v. i. To drift sidewise or to leeward  as a vessel.

Crab: C r a b "a. Sour; rough; austere.

Crab tree: C r a b   t r e e " See under Crab.

Crab-yaws: C r a b - y a w s "n. A disease in the West Indies. It is a kind of ulcer on the soles of the feet  with very hard edges. See Yaws.

Crabbed: C r a b b e d "n. Characterized by or manifesting  sourness peevishness or moroseness; harsh; cross; cynical; -- applied to feelings disposition or manners.

Crabbed: C r a b b e d "n. Characterized by harshness or roughness; unpleasant; -- applied to things; as  a crabbed taste.

Crabbed: C r a b b e d "n. Obscure; difficult; perplexing; trying; as  a crabbed author.

Crabbed: C r a b b e d "n. Cramped; irregular; as  crabbed handwriting.

Crabber: C r a b b e r "n. One who catches crabs.

Crabbing: C r a b b i n g "n. The fighting of hawks with each other.

Crabbing: C r a b b i n g "n. A process of scouring cloth between rolls in a machine.

Crabbish: C r a b b i s h "a. Somewhat sour or cross.

Crabby: C r a b b y "a. Crabbed; difficult  or perplexing.

Crabeater: C r a b e a t e r "n. The cobia.

Crabeater: C r a b e a t e r "n. An etheostomoid fish of the southern United States (Hadropterus nigrofasciatus).

Crabeater: C r a b e a t e r "n. A small European heron (Ardea minuta  and other allied species).

Craber: C r a b e r "n. The water rat.

Crabfaced: C r a b f a c e d "a. Having a sour  disagreeable countenance.

Crabsidle: C r a b s i d l e "v. i. To move sidewise  as a crab. [Jocular].

Crabstick: C r a b s t i c k "n. A stick  cane or cudgel made of the wood of the crab tree.

Crache: C r a c h e "v. To scratch.

Crack: C r a c k "v. t. To break or burst  with or without entire separation of the parts; as to crack glass; to crack nuts.

Crack: C r a c k "v. t. To rend with grief or pain; to affect deeply with sorrow; hence  to disorder; to distract; to craze.

Crack: C r a c k "v. t. To cause to sound suddenly and sharply; to snap; as  to crack a whip.

Crack: C r a c k "v. t. To utter smartly and sententiously; as  to crack a joke.

Crack: C r a c k "v. t. To cry up; to extol; -- followed by up.

Crack: C r a c k "v. i. To burst or open in chinks; to break  with or without quite separating into parts.

Crack: C r a c k "v. i. To be ruined or impaired; to fail.

Crack: C r a c k "v. i. To utter a loud or sharp  sudden sound.

Crack: C r a c k "v. i. To utter vain  pompous words; to brag; to boast; -- with of.

Crack: C r a c k "n. A partial separation of parts  with or without a perceptible opening; a chink or fissure; a narrow breach; a crevice; as a crack in timber or in a wall or in glass.

Crack: C r a c k "n. Rupture; flaw; breach  in a moral sense.

Crack: C r a c k "n. A sharp  sudden sound or report; the sound of anything suddenly burst or broken; as the crack of a falling house; the crack of thunder; the crack of a whip.

Crack: C r a c k "n. The tone of voice when changed at puberty.

Crack: C r a c k "n. Mental flaw; a touch of craziness; partial insanity; as  he has a crack.

Crack: C r a c k "n. A crazy or crack-brained person.

Crack: C r a c k "n. A boast; boasting.

Crack: C r a c k "n. Breach of chastity.

Crack: C r a c k "n. A boy  generally a pert lively boy.

Crack: C r a c k "n. A brief time; an instant; as  to be with one in a crack.

Crack: C r a c k "n. Free conversation; friendly chat.

Crack: C r a c k "a. Of superior excellence; having qualities to be boasted of.

Crack-brained: C r a c k - b r a i n e d "a. Having an impaired intellect; whimsical; crazy.

Cracked: C r a c k e d "imp. & p. p. of Crack

Cracked: C r a c k e d "a. Coarsely ground or broken; as  cracked wheat.

Cracked: C r a c k e d "a. Crack-brained.

Cracker: C r a c k e r "n. One who  or that which cracks.

Cracker: C r a c k e r "n. A noisy boaster; a swaggering fellow.

Cracker: C r a c k e r "n. A small firework  consisting of a little powder inclosed in a thick paper cylinder with a fuse and exploding with a sharp noise; -- often called firecracker.

Cracker: C r a c k e r "n. A thin  dry biscuit often hard or crisp; as a Boston cracker; a Graham cracker; a soda cracker; an oyster cracker.

Cracker: C r a c k e r "n. A nickname to designate a poor white in some parts of the Southern United States.

Cracker: C r a c k e r "n. The pintail duck.

Cracker: C r a c k e r "n. A pair of fluted rolls for grinding caoutchouc.

Crackle: C r a c k l e "v. i. To make slight cracks; to make small  sharp sudden noises rapidly or frequently repeated; to crepitate; as burning thorns crackle.

Crackle: C r a c k l e "n. The noise of slight and frequent cracks or reports; a crackling.

Crackle: C r a c k l e "n. A kind of crackling sound or r/le  heard in some abnormal states of the lungs; as dry crackle; moist crackle.

Crackle: C r a c k l e "n. A condition produced in certain porcelain  fine earthenware or glass in which the glaze or enamel appears to be cracked in all directions making a sort of reticulated surface; as Chinese crackle; Bohemian crackle.

Crackled: C r a c k l e d "a. Covered with minute cracks in the glaze; -- said of some kinds of porcelain and fine earthenware.

Crackleware: C r a c k l e w a r e "n. See Crackle  n. 3.

Crackling: C r a c k l i n g "n. The making of small  sharp cracks or reports frequently repeated.

Crackling: C r a c k l i n g "n. The well-browned  crisp rind of roasted pork.

Crackling: C r a c k l i n g "n. Food for dogs  made from the refuse of tallow melting.

Cracknel: C r a c k n e l "v. t. A hard brittle cake or biscuit.

Cracksman: C r a c k s m a n "n. A burglar.
