Cracovian: C r a c o v i a n "a. Of or pertaining to Cracow in Poland.

Cracovienne: C r a c o v i e n n e "n. A lively Polish dance  in 2-4 time.

Cracowes: C r a c o w e s "n. pl. Long-toed boots or shoes formerly worn in many parts of Europe; -- so called from Cracow  in Poland where they were first worn in the fourteenth century.

Cradgedness: C r a d g e d n e s s "n. The quality or state of being cragged; cragginess.

Cradle: C r a d l e "n. A bed or cot for a baby  oscillating on rockers or swinging on pivots; hence the place of origin or in which anything is nurtured or protected in the earlier period of existence; as a cradle of crime; the cradle of liberty.

Cradle: C r a d l e "n. Infancy  or very early life.

Cradle: C r a d l e "n. An implement consisting of a broad scythe for cutting grain  with a set of long fingers parallel to the scythe designed to receive the grain and to lay it evenly in a swath.

Cradle: C r a d l e "n. A tool used in mezzotint engraving  which by a rocking motion raises burrs on the surface of the plate so preparing the ground.

Cradle: C r a d l e "n. A framework of timbers  or iron bars moving upon ways or rollers used to support lift or carry ships or other vessels heavy guns etc. as up an inclined plane or across a strip of land or in launching a ship.

Cradle: C r a d l e "n. A case for a broken or dislocated limb.

Cradle: C r a d l e "n. A frame to keep the bedclothes from contact with the person.

Cradle: C r a d l e "n. A machine on rockers  used in washing out auriferous earth; -- also called a rocker.

Cradle: C r a d l e "n. A suspended scaffold used in shafts.

Cradle: C r a d l e "n. The ribbing for vaulted ceilings and arches intended to be covered with plaster.

Cradle: C r a d l e "n. The basket or apparatus in which  when a line has been made fast to a wrecked ship from the shore the people are brought off from the wreck.

Cradle: C r a d l e "v. t. To lay to rest  or rock as in a cradle; to lull or quiet as by rocking.

Cradle: C r a d l e "v. t. To nurse or train in infancy.

Cradle: C r a d l e "v. t. To cut and lay with a cradle  as grain.

Cradle: C r a d l e "v. t. To transport a vessel by means of a cradle.

Cradle: C r a d l e "v. i. To lie or lodge  as in a cradle.

Cradling: C r a d l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Cradle

Cradling: C r a d l i n g "n. The act of using a cradle.

Cradling: C r a d l i n g "n. Cutting a cask into two pieces lengthwise  to enable it to pass a narrow place the two parts being afterward united and rehooped.

Cradling: C r a d l i n g "n. The framework in arched or coved ceilings to which the laths are nailed.

Craft: C r a f t "n. Strength; might; secret power.

Craft: C r a f t "n. Art or skill; dexterity in particular manual employment; hence  the occupation or employment itself; manual art; a trade.

Craft: C r a f t "n. Those engaged in any trade  taken collectively; a guild; as the craft of ironmongers.

Craft: C r a f t "n. Cunning  art or skill in a bad sense or applied to bad purposes; artifice; guile; skill or dexterity employed to effect purposes by deceit or shrewd devices.

Craft: C r a f t "n. A vessel; vessels of any kind; -- generally used in a collective sense.

Craft: C r a f t "v. t. To play tricks; to practice artifice.

Craftily: C r a f t i l y "adv. With craft; artfully; cunningly.

Craftiness: C r a f t i n e s s "n. Dexterity in devising and effecting a purpose; cunning; artifice; stratagem.

Craftless: C r a f t l e s s "a. Without craft or cunning.

Cragged: C r a g g e d "a. Full of crags  or steep broken //cks; abounding with prominences points and inequalities; rough; rugged.

Cragginess: C r a g g i n e s s "n. The state of being craggy.

Craggy: C r a g g y "a. Full of crags; rugged with projecting points of rocks; as  the craggy side of a mountain.

Cragsman: C r a g s m a n "n. One accustomed to climb rocks or crags; esp.  one who makes a business of climbing the cliffs overhanging the sea to get the eggs of sea birds or the birds themselves.

Cram: C r a m "v. t. To press  force or drive particularly in filling or in thrusting one thing into another; to stuff; to crowd; to fill to superfluity; as to cram anything into a basket; to cram a room with people.

Cram: C r a m "v. t. To fill with food to satiety; to stuff.

Cram: C r a m "v. t. To put hastily through an extensive course of memorizing or study  as in preparation for an examination; as a pupil is crammed by his tutor.

Cram: C r a m "n. The act of cramming.

Cramp: C r a m p "n. That which confines or contracts; a restraint; a shackle; a hindrance.

Cramp: C r a m p "n. A device  usually of iron bent at the ends used to hold together blocks of stone timbers etc.; a cramp iron.

Cramp: C r a m p "n. A rectangular frame  with a tightening screw used for compressing the joints of framework etc.

Cramp: C r a m p "n. A piece of wood having a curve corresponding to that of the upper part of the instep  on which the upper leather of a boot is stretched to give it the requisite shape.

Cramp: C r a m p "n. A spasmodic and painful involuntary contraction of a muscle or muscles  as of the leg.

Crampoons: C r a m p o o n s "n. Iron instruments with sharp points  worn on the shoes to assist in gaining or keeping a foothold.

Cran: C r a n "n. Alt. of Crane

Cranage: C r a n a g e "n. The liberty of using a crane  as for loading and unloading vessels.

Cranage: C r a n a g e "n. The money or price paid for the use of a crane.

Cranberries: C r a n b e r r i e s "pl. "of Cranberry

Cranberry: C r a n b e r r y "n. A red  acid berry much used for making sauce etc.; also the plant producing it (several species of Vaccinum or Oxycoccus.) The high cranberry or cranberry tree is a species of Viburnum (V. Opulus) and the other is sometimes called low cranberry or marsh cranberry to distinguish it.

Cranch: C r a n c h "v. t. See Craunch.

Crane: C r a n e "n. A measure for fresh herrings  -- as many as will fill a barrel.

Crane: C r a n e "n. A wading bird of the genus Grus  and allied genera of various species having a long straight bill and long legs and neck.

Crane: C r a n e "n. A machine for raising and lowering heavy weights  and while holding them suspended transporting them through a limited lateral distance. In one form it consists of a projecting arm or jib of timber or iron a rotating post or base and the necessary tackle windlass etc.; -- so called from a fancied similarity between its arm and the neck of a crane See Illust. of Derrick.

Crane: C r a n e "n. An iron arm with horizontal motion  attached to the side or back of a fireplace for supporting kettles etc. over a fire.

Crane: C r a n e "n. A siphon  or bent pipe for drawing liquors out of a cask.

Crane: C r a n e "n. A forked post or projecting bracket to support spars  etc. -- generally used in pairs. See Crotch 2.

Crane: C r a n e "v. t. To cause to rise; to raise or lift  as by a crane; -- with up.

Crane: C r a n e "v. t. To stretch  as a crane stretches its neck; as to crane the neck disdainfully.

Crane: C r a n e "v. i. to reach forward with head and neck  in order to see better; as a hunter cranes forward before taking a leap.

Crane's-bill: C r a n e ' s - b i l l "n. The geranium; -- so named from the long axis of the fruit  which resembles the beak of a crane.

Crane's-bill: C r a n e ' s - b i l l "n. A pair of long-beaked forceps.

Crania: C r a n i a "n. A genus of living Brachiopoda; -- so called from its fancied resemblance to the cranium or skull.

Cranioclasm: C r a n i o c l a s m "n. The crushing of a child's head  as with the cranioclast or craniotomy forceps in cases of very difficult delivery.

Cranioclast: C r a n i o c l a s t "n. An instrument for crushing the head of a fetus  to facilitate delivery in difficult eases.

Craniofacial: C r a n i o f a c i a l "a. Of or pertaining to the cranium and face; as  the craniofacial angle.

Craniognomy: C r a n i o g n o m y "n. The science of the form and characteristics of the skull.

Craniological: C r a n i o l o g i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to craniology.

Craniologist: C r a n i o l o g i s t "n. One proficient in craniology; a phrenologist.

Craniology: C r a n i o l o g y "n. The department of science (as of ethnology or archaeology) which deals with the shape  size proportions indications etc. of skulls; the study of skulls.

Craniometer: C r a n i o m e t e r "n. An instrument for measuring the size of skulls.

Craniometric: C r a n i o m e t r i c "a. Alt. of Craniometrical

Craniometrical: C r a n i o m e t r i c a l "a. Pertaining to craniometry.

Craniometry: C r a n i o m e t r y "n. The art or act of measuring skulls.

Cranioscopist: C r a n i o s c o p i s t "n. One skilled in  or who practices cranioscopy.

Cranioscopy: C r a n i o s c o p y "n. Scientific examination of the cranium.

Craniota: C r a n i o t a "n. pl. A comprehensive division of the Vertebrata  including all those that have a skull.

Craniotomy: C r a n i o t o m y "n. The operation of opening the fetal head  in order to effect delivery.

Cranium: C r a n i u m "n. The skull of an animal; especially  that part of the skull either cartilaginous or bony which immediately incloses the brain; the brain case or brainpan. See Skull.

Craniums: C r a n i u m s "pl. "of Cranium

Crank: C r a n k "n. A bent portion of an axle  or shaft or an arm keyed at right angles to the end of a shaft by which motion is imparted to or received from it; also used to change circular into reciprocating motion or reciprocating into circular motion. See Bell crank.

Crank: C r a n k "n. Any bend  turn or winding as of a passage.

Crank: C r a n k "n. A twist or turn in speech; a conceit consisting in a change of the form or meaning of a word.

Crank: C r a n k "n. A twist or turn of the mind; caprice; whim; crotchet; also  a fit of temper or passion.

Crank: C r a n k "n. A person full of crotchets; one given to fantastic or impracticable projects; one whose judgment is perverted in respect to a particular matter.

Crank: C r a n k "n. A sick person; an invalid.

Crank: C r a n k "n. Sick; infirm.

Crank: C r a n k "n. Liable to careen or be overset  as a ship when she is too narrow or has not sufficient ballast or is loaded too high to carry full sail.

Crank: C r a n k "n. Full of spirit; brisk; lively; sprightly; overconfident; opinionated.

Crank: C r a n k "n. To run with a winding course; to double; to crook; to wind and turn.

Crankbird: C r a n k b i r d "n. A small European woodpecker (Picus minor).

Crannies: C r a n n i e s "pl. "of Cranny

Crannog: C r a n n o g "n. Alt. of Crannoge

Crannoge: C r a n n o g e "n. One of the stockaded islands in Scotland and Ireland which in ancient times were numerous in the lakes of both countries. They may be regarded as the very latest class of prehistoric strongholds  reaching their greatest development in early historic times and surviving through the Middle Ages. See also Lake dwellings under Lake.

Cranny: C r a n n y "n. A small  narrow opening fissure crevice or chink as in a wall or other substance.

Cranny: C r a n n y "n. A tool for forming the necks of bottles  etc.

Cranny: C r a n n y "v. i. To crack into  or become full of crannies.

Crape: C r a p e "n. A thin  crimped stuff made of raw silk gummed and twisted on the mill. Black crape is much used for mourning garments also for the dress of some clergymen.

Crate: C r a t e "n. A box or case whose sides are of wooden slats with interspaces  -- used especially for transporting fruit.

Crater: C r a t e r "n. The basinlike opening or mouth of a volcano  through which the chief eruption comes; similarly the mouth of a geyser about which a cone of silica is often built up.

Crater: C r a t e r "n. The pit left by the explosion of a mine.

Crater: C r a t e r "n. A constellation of the southen hemisphere; -- called also the Cup.

Crateriform: C r a t e r i f o r m "a. Having the form of a shallow bowl; -- said of a corolla.

Crave: C r a v e "v. t. To ask with earnestness or importunity; to ask with submission or humility; to beg; to entreat; to beseech; to implore.

Crave: C r a v e "v. t. To call for  as a gratification; to long for; hence to require or demand; as the stomach craves food.

Crave: C r a v e "v. i. To desire strongly; to feel an insatiable longing; as  a craving appetite.

Craw: C r a w "n. The crop of a bird.

Craw: C r a w "n. The stomach of an animal.

Crawfish: C r a w f i s h "n. Alt. of Crayfish

Crawford: C r a w f o r d "n. A Crawford peach; a well-known freestone peach  with yellow flesh first raised by Mr. William Crawford of New Jersey.

Crawl: C r a w l "v. i. To move slowly by drawing the body along the ground  as a worm; to move slowly on hands and knees; to creep.

Crawl: C r a w l "v. i. to move or advance in a feeble  slow or timorous manner.

Crawl: C r a w l "v. i. To advance slowly and furtively; to insinuate one's self; to advance or gain influence by servile or obsequious conduct.

Crawl: C r a w l "v. i. To have a sensation as of insect creeping over the body; as  the flesh crawls. See Creep v. i. 7.

Crawl: C r a w l "n. The act or motion of crawling; slow motion  as of a creeping animal.

Crawl: C r a w l "n. A pen or inclosure of stakes and hurdles on the seacoast  for holding fish.

Crawled: C r a w l e d "imp. & p. p. of Crawl

Crawler: C r a w l e r "n. One who  or that which crawls; a creeper; a reptile.

Crawling: C r a w l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Crawl

Crawly: C r a w l y "a. Creepy.

Cray: C r a y "n. Alt. of Crayer

Crayer: C r a y e r "n. See Crare.

Crayfish: C r a y f i s h "n. Any crustacean of the family Astacidae  resembling the lobster but smaller and found in fresh waters. Crawfishes are esteemed very delicate food both in Europe and America. The North American species are numerous and mostly belong to the genus Cambarus. The blind crawfish of the Mammoth Cave is Cambarus pellucidus. The common European species is Astacus fluviatilis.

Crayfish: C r a y f i s h "n. See Crawfish.

Crayon: C r a y o n "n. An implement for drawing  made of clay and plumbago or of some preparation of chalk usually sold in small prisms or cylinders.

Crayon: C r a y o n "n. A crayon drawing.

Crayon: C r a y o n "n. A pencil of carbon used in producing electric light.

Crayon: C r a y o n "v. t. To sketch  as with a crayon; to sketch or plan.

Crayoned: C r a y o n e d "imp. & p. p. of Crayon

Crayoning: C r a y o n i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Crayon

Craze: C r a z e "v. t. To break into pieces; to crush; to grind to powder. See Crase.

Craze: C r a z e "v. t. To weaken; to impair; to render decrepit.

Craze: C r a z e "v. t. To derange the intellect of; to render insane.

Craze: C r a z e "v. i. To be crazed  or to act or appear as one that is crazed; to rave; to become insane.

Craze: C r a z e "v. i. To crack  as the glazing of porcelain or pottery.

Craze: C r a z e "n. Craziness; insanity.

Craze: C r a z e "n. A strong habitual desire or fancy; a crotchet.

Craze: C r a z e "n. A temporary passion or infatuation  as for same new amusement pursuit or fashion; as the bric-a-brac craze; the aesthetic craze.

Craziness: C r a z i n e s s "n. The state of being broken in mind; imbecility or weakness of intellect; derangement.

Crazy: C r a z y "a. Inordinately desirous; foolishly eager.

Cream: C r e a m "n. The rich  oily and yellowish part of milk which when the milk stands unagitated rises and collects on the surface. It is the part of milk from which butter is obtained.

Cream: C r e a m "n. The part of any liquor that rises  and collects on the surface.

Cream: C r e a m "n. A delicacy of several kinds prepared for the table from cream  etc. or so as to resemble cream.

Cream: C r e a m "n. A cosmetic; a creamlike medicinal preparation.

Cream: C r e a m "n. The best or choicest part of a thing; the quintessence; as  the cream of a jest or story; the cream of a collection of books or pictures.

Cream: C r e a m "v. t. To skim  or take off by skimming as cream.

Cream: C r e a m "v. t. To take off the best or choicest part of.

Cream: C r e a m "v. t. To furnish with  or as with cream.

Cream: C r e a m "v. i. To form or become covered with cream; to become thick like cream; to assume the appearance of cream; hence  to grow stiff or formal; to mantle.

Cream laid: C r e a m   l a i d " See under Laid.

Cream-colored: C r e a m - c o l o r e d "a. Of the color of cream; light yellow.

Cream-faced: C r e a m - f a c e d "a. White or pale  as the effect of fear or as the natural complexion.

Cream-fruit: C r e a m - f r u i t "n. A plant of Sierra Leone which yields a wholesome  creamy juice.

Cream-slice: C r e a m - s l i c e "n. A wooden knife with a long thin blade  used in handling cream or ice cream.

Cream-white: C r e a m - w h i t e "a. As white as cream.

Creamery: C r e a m e r y "n. A place or apparatus in which milk is set for raising cream.

Creamery: C r e a m e r y "n. An establishment where cream is sold.

Crease: C r e a s e "n. A line or mark made by folding or doubling any pliable substance; hence  a similar mark however produced.

Creatable: C r e a t a b l e "a. That may be created.

Create: C r e a t e "a. Created; composed; begotten.

Create: C r e a t e "v. t. To bring into being; to form out of nothing; to cause to exist.

Create: C r e a t e "v. t. To effect by the agency  and under the laws of causation; to be the occasion of; to cause; to produce; to form or fashion; to renew.

Create: C r e a t e "v. t. To invest with a new form  office or character; to constitute; to appoint; to make; as to create one a peer.

Created: C r e a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Create

Creatic: C r e a t i c "a. Relating to  or produced by flesh or animal food; as creatic nausea.

Creatin: C r e a t i n "n. A white  crystalline nitrogenous substance found abundantly in muscle tissue.

Creating: C r e a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Create

Creatinin: C r e a t i n i n "n. A white  crystalline nitrogenous body closely related to creatin but more basic in its properties formed from the latter by the action of acids and occurring naturally in muscle tissue and in urine.

Creation: C r e a t i o n "n. The act of creating or causing to exist. Specifically  the act of bringing the universe or this world into existence.

Creation: C r e a t i o n "n. That which is created; that which is produced or caused to exist  as the world or some original work of art or of the imagination; nature.

Creation: C r e a t i o n "n. The act of constituting or investing with a new character; appointment; formation.

Creational: C r e a t i o n a l "a. Of or pertaining to creation.

Creationism: C r e a t i o n i s m "n. The doctrine that a soul is specially created for each human being as soon as it is formed in the womb; -- opposed to traducianism.

Creative: C r e a t i v e "a. Having the power to create; exerting the act of creation.

Creativeness: C r e a t i v e n e s s "n. The quality of being creative.

Creatorship: C r e a t o r s h i p "n. State or condition of a creator.

Creatress: C r e a t r e s s "n. She who creates.

Creatrix: C r e a t r i x "n. A creatress.

Creatural: C r e a t u r a l "a. Belonging to a creature; having the qualities of a creature.

Creature: C r e a t u r e "n. Anything created; anything not self-existent; especially  any being created with life; an animal; a man.

Creature: C r e a t u r e "n. A human being  in pity contempt or endearment; as a poor creature; a pretty creature.

Creature: C r e a t u r e "n. A person who owes his rise and fortune to another; a servile dependent; an instrument; a tool.

Creature: C r e a t u r e "n. A general term among farmers for horses  oxen etc.

Creaturely: C r e a t u r e l y "a. Creatural; characteristic of a creature.

Creatureship: C r e a t u r e s h i p "n. The condition of being a creature.

Creaturize: C r e a t u r i z e "v. t. To make like a creature; to degrade

Creaze: C r e a z e "n. The tin ore which collects in the central part of the washing pit or buddle.

Credence: C r e d e n c e "n. Reliance of the mind on evidence of facts derived from other sources than personal knowledge; belief; credit; confidence.

Credence: C r e d e n c e "n. That which gives a claim to credit  belief or confidence; as a letter of credence.

Credence: C r e d e n c e "n. The small table by the side of the altar or communion table  on which the bread and wine are placed before being consecrated.

Credence: C r e d e n c e "n. A cupboard  sideboard or cabinet particularly one intended for the display of rich vessels or plate and consisting chiefly of open shelves for that purpose.

Credence: C r e d e n c e "v. t. To give credence to; to believe.

Credenda: C r e d e n d a "pl. "of Credendum

Credendum: C r e d e n d u m "n. A thing to be believed; an article of faith; -- distinguished from agendum  a practical duty.

Credent: C r e d e n t "a. Believing; giving credence; credulous.

Credent: C r e d e n t "a. Having credit or authority; credible.

Credential: C r e d e n t i a l "a. Giving a title or claim to credit or confidence; accrediting.

Credential: C r e d e n t i a l "n. That which gives a title to credit or confidence.

Credential: C r e d e n t i a l "n. Testimonials showing that a person is entitled to credit  or has right to exercise official power as the letters given by a government to an ambassador or envoy or a certificate that one is a duly elected delegate.

Credibility: C r e d i b i l i t y "n. The quality of being credible; credibleness; as  the credibility of facts; the credibility of witnesses.

Credible: C r e d i b l e "a. Capable of being credited or believed; worthy of belief; entitled to confidence; trustworthy.

Credibleness: C r e d i b l e n e s s "n. The quality or state of being credible; worthiness of belief; credibility.

Credibly: C r e d i b l y "adv. In a manner inducing belief; as  I have been credibly informed of the event.

Credit: C r e d i t "n. Reliance on the truth of something said or done; belief; faith; trust; confidence.

Credit: C r e d i t "n. Reputation derived from the confidence of others; esteem; honor; good name; estimation.

Credit: C r e d i t "n. A ground of  or title to belief or confidence; authority derived from character or reputation.

Credit: C r e d i t "n. That which tends to procure  or add to reputation or esteem; an honor.

Credit: C r e d i t "n. Influence derived from the good opinion  confidence or favor of others; interest.

Credit: C r e d i t "n. Trust given or received; expectation of future playment for property transferred  or of fulfillment or promises given; mercantile reputation entitling one to be trusted; -- applied to individuals corporations communities or nations; as to buy goods on credit.

Credit: C r e d i t "n. The time given for payment for lands or goods sold on trust; as  a long credit or a short credit.

Credit: C r e d i t "n. The side of an account on which are entered all items reckoned as values received from the party or the category named at the head of the account; also  any one or the sum of these items; -- the opposite of debit; as this sum is carried to one's credit and that to his debit; A has several credits on the books of B.

Credit: C r e d i t "v. t. To confide in the truth of; to give credence to; to put trust in; to believe.

Credit: C r e d i t "v. t. To bring honor or repute upon; to do credit to; to raise the estimation of.

Credit: C r e d i t "v. t. To enter upon the credit side of an account; to give credit for; as  to credit the amount paid; to set to the credit of; as to credit a man with the interest paid on a bond.

Credit foncier: C r e d i t   f o n c i e r " A company licensed for the purpose of carrying out improvements  by means of loans and advances upon real securities.

Credit mobilier: C r e d i t   m o b i l i e r " A joint stock company  formed for general banking business or for the construction of public works by means of loans on personal estate after the manner of the credit foncier on real estate. In practice however this distinction has not been strictly observed.

Creditable: C r e d i t a b l e "a. Worthy of belief.

Creditable: C r e d i t a b l e "a. Deserving or possessing reputation or esteem; reputable; estimable.

Creditable: C r e d i t a b l e "a. Bringing credit  reputation or honor; honorable; as such conduct is highly creditable to him.

Creditableness: C r e d i t a b l e n e s s "n. The quality of being creditable.

Creditably: C r e d i t a b l y "adv. In a creditable manner; reputably; with credit.

Credited: C r e d i t e d "imp. & p. p. of Credit

Crediting: C r e d i t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Credit

Creditor: C r e d i t o r "n. One who credits  believes or trusts.

Creditor: C r e d i t o r "n. One who gives credit in business matters; hence  one to whom money is due; -- correlative to debtor.

Creditress: C r e d i t r e s s "n. Alt. of Creditrix

Creditrix: C r e d i t r i x "n. A female creditor.

Credo: C r e d o "n. The creed  as sung or read in the Roman Catholic church.

Credulity: C r e d u l i t y "n. Readiness of belief; a disposition to believe on slight evidence.

Credulous: C r e d u l o u s "a. Apt to believe on slight evidence; easily imposed upon; unsuspecting.

Credulous: C r e d u l o u s "a. Believed too readily.

Credulously: C r e d u l o u s l y "adv. With credulity.

Credulousness: C r e d u l o u s n e s s "n. Readiness to believe on slight evidence; credulity.

Creed: C r e e d "v. t. A definite summary of what is believed; esp.  a summary of the articles of Christian faith; a confession of faith for public use; esp. one which is brief and comprehensive.

Creed: C r e e d "v. t. Any summary of principles or opinions professed or adhered to.

Creed: C r e e d "v. t. To believe; to credit.

Creedless: C r e e d l e s s "a. Without a creed.

Creek: C r e e k "n. A small inlet or bay  narrower and extending further into the land than a cove; a recess in the shore of the sea or of a river.

Creek: C r e e k "n. A stream of water smaller than a river and larger than a brook.

Creek: C r e e k "n. Any turn or winding.

Creekfish: C r e e k f i s h "n. The chub sucker.

Creeks: C r e e k s "n. pl. A tribe or confederacy of North American Indians  including the Muskogees Seminoles Uchees and other subordinate tribes. They formerly inhabited Georgia Florida and Alabama.

Creeky: C r e e k y "a. Containing  or abounding in creeks; characterized by creeks; like a creek; winding.

Creel: C r e e l "n. An osier basket  such as anglers use.

Creel: C r e e l "n. A bar or set of bars with skewers for holding paying-off bobbins  as in the roving machine throstle and mule.

Creep: C r e e p "v. t. To move along the ground  or on any other surface on the belly as a worm or reptile; to move as a child on the hands and knees; to crawl.

Creep: C r e e p "v. t. To move slowly  feebly or timorously as from unwillingness fear or weakness.

Creep: C r e e p "v. t. To move in a stealthy or secret manner; to move imperceptibly or clandestinely; to steal in; to insinuate itself or one's self; as  age creeps upon us.

Creep: C r e e p "v. t. To slip  or to become slightly displaced; as the collodion on a negative or a coat of varnish may creep in drying; the quicksilver on a mirror may creep.

Creep: C r e e p "v. t. To move or behave with servility or exaggerated humility; to fawn; as  a creeping sycophant.

Creep: C r e e p "v. t. To grow  as a vine clinging to the ground or to some other support by means of roots or rootlets or by tendrils along its length.

Creep: C r e e p "v. t. To have a sensation as of insects creeping on the skin of the body; to crawl; as  the sight made my flesh creep. See Crawl v. i. 4.

Creep: C r e e p "v. i. To drag in deep water with creepers  as for recovering a submarine cable.

Creep: C r e e p "n. The act or process of creeping.

Creep: C r e e p "n. A distressing sensation  or sound like that occasioned by the creeping of insects.

Creep: C r e e p "n. A slow rising of the floor of a gallery  occasioned by the pressure of incumbent strata upon the pillars or sides; a gradual movement of mining ground.

Creeper: C r e e p e r "n. One who  or that which creeps; any creeping thing.

Creeper: C r e e p e r "n. A plant that clings by rootlets  or by tendrils to the ground or to trees etc.; as the Virginia creeper (Ampelopsis quinquefolia).

Creeper: C r e e p e r "n. A small bird of the genus Certhia  allied to the wrens. The brown or common European creeper is C. familiaris a variety of which (var. Americana) inhabits America; -- called also tree creeper and creeptree. The American black and white creeper is Mniotilta varia.

Creeper: C r e e p e r "n. A kind of patten mounted on short pieces of iron instead of rings; also  a fixture with iron points worn on a shoe to prevent one from slipping.

Creeper: C r e e p e r "n. A spurlike device strapped to the boot  which enables one to climb a tree or pole; -- called often telegraph creepers.

Creeper: C r e e p e r "n. A small  low iron or dog between the andirons.

Creeper: C r e e p e r "n. An instrument with iron hooks or claws for dragging at the bottom of a well  or any other body of water and bringing up what may lie there.

Creeper: C r e e p e r "n. Any device for causing material to move steadily from one part of a machine to another  as an apron in a carding machine or an inner spiral in a grain screen.

Creeper: C r e e p e r "n. Crockets. See Crocket.

Creephole: C r e e p h o l e "n. A hole or retreat into which an animal may creep  to escape notice or danger.

Creephole: C r e e p h o l e "n. A subterfuge; an excuse.

Creepie: C r e e p i e "n. A low stool.

Creepiness: C r e e p i n e s s "n. An uneasy sensation as of insects creeping on the skin.

Creeping: C r e e p i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Creep

Creeping: C r e e p i n g "a. Crawling  or moving close to the ground.

Creeping: C r e e p i n g "a. Growing along  and clinging to the ground or to a wall etc. by means of rootlets or tendrils.

Creepingly: C r e e p i n g l y "adv. by creeping slowly; in the manner of a reptile; insidiously; cunningly.

Creeple: C r e e p l e "n. A creeping creature; a reptile.

Creeple: C r e e p l e "n. One who is lame; a cripple.

Creepy: C r e e p y "a. Crawly; having or producing a sensation like that caused by insects creeping on the skin.

Crees: C r e e s "n. pl. An Algonquin tribe of Indians  inhabiting a large part of British America east of the Rocky Mountains and south of Hudson's Bay.

Creese: C r e e s e "n. A dagger or short sword used by the Malays  commonly having a serpentine blade.

Crefting: C r e f t i n g "n. Croftland.

Crefting: C r e f t i n g "n. Exposing linen to the sun  on the grass in the process of bleaching.

Cremaillere: C r e m a i l l e r e "n. An indented or zigzaged line of intrenchment.

Cremaster: C r e m a s t e r "n. A thin muscle which serves to draw up the testicle.

Cremaster: C r e m a s t e r "n. The apex of the last abdominal segment of an insect.

Cremasteric: C r e m a s t e r i c "a. Of or pertaining to the cremaster; as  the cremasteric artery.

Cremate: C r e m a t e "v. t. To burn; to reduce to ashes by the action of fire  either directly or in an oven or retort; to incremate or incinerate; as to cremate a corpse instead of burying it.

Cremation: C r e m a t i o n "n. A burning; esp.  the act or practice of cremating the dead.

Cremationist: C r e m a t i o n i s t "n. One who advocates the practice of cremation.

Cremator: C r e m a t o r "n. One who  or that which cremates or consumes to ashes.

Crematories: C r e m a t o r i e s "pl. "of Crematory

Crematorium: C r e m a t o r i u m "n. Alt. of Crematory

Crematoriums: C r e m a t o r i u m s "pl. "of Crematory

Crematory: C r e m a t o r y "n. A furnace for cremating corpses; a building containing such a furnace.

Crematory: C r e m a t o r y "a. Pertaining to  or employed in cremation.

Cremocarp: C r e m o c a r p "n. The peculiar fruit of fennel  carrot parsnip and the like consisting of a pair of carpels pendent from a supporting axis.

Cremona: C r e m o n a "n. A superior kind of violin  formerly made at Cremona in Italy.

Cremor: C r e m o r "n. Cream; a substance resembling cream; yeast; scum.

Cremosin: C r e m o s i n "n. See Crimson.

Crems: C r e m s "n. See Krems.

Crenate: C r e n a t e "a. Alt. of Crenated

Crenated: C r e n a t e d "a. Having the margin cut into rounded teeth notches  or scallops.

Crenation: C r e n a t i o n "n. A rounded tooth on the edge of a leaf.

Crenation: C r e n a t i o n "n. The condition of being crenate.

Crenature: C r e n a t u r e "n. A rounded tooth or notch of a crenate leaf  or any part that is crenate; -- called also crenelle.

Crenature: C r e n a t u r e "n. The state of being crenated or notched.

Crenel: C r e n e l "n. See Crenelle.

Crenel: C r e n e l "n. An embrasure or indentation in a battlement; a loophole in a fortress; an indentation; a notch. See Merlon  and Illust. of Battlement.

Crenel: C r e n e l "n. Same as Crenature.

Crenelate: C r e n e l a t e "v. t. To furnish with crenelles.

Crenelate: C r e n e l a t e "v. t. To indent; to notch; as  a crenelated leaf.

Crenelled: C r e n e l l e d "a. Same as Crenate.

Crenkle: C r e n k l e "n. See Cringle.

Crenulated: C r e n u l a t e d "a. Minutely crenate.

Crenulation: C r e n u l a t i o n "n. The state of being minutely scalloped.

Creole: C r e o l e "n. One born of European parents in the American colonies of France or Spain or in the States which were once such colonies  esp. a person of French or Spanish descent who is a native inhabitant of Louisiana or one of the States adjoining bordering on the Gulf of of Mexico.

Creole: C r e o l e "a. Of or pertaining to a Creole or the Creoles.

Creolean: C r e o l e a n "a. Alt. of Creolian

Creolian: C r e o l i a n "a. Pertaining to  or characteristic of the Creoles.

Creolian: C r e o l i a n "n. "A Creole.

Creosol: C r e o s o l "n. A colorless liquid resembling phenol or carbolic acid  homologous with pyrocatechin and obtained from beechwood tar and gum guaiacum.

Creosote: C r e o s o t e "n. Wood-tar oil; an oily antiseptic liquid  of a burning smoky taste colorless when pure but usually colored yellow or brown by impurity or exposure. It is a complex mixture of various phenols and their ethers and is obtained by the distillation of wood tar especially that of beechwood.

Creosote: C r e o s o t e "v. t. To saturate or impregnate with creosote  as timber for the prevention of decay.

Creosoted: C r e o s o t e d "imp. & p. p. of Creosote

Creosoting: C r e o s o t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Creosote

Crepance: C r e p a n c e "n. Alt. of Crepane

Crepane: C r e p a n e "n. An injury in a horse's leg  caused by the shoe of one hind foot striking and cutting the other leg. It sometimes forms an ulcer.

Crepe: C r e p e "n. Same as Crape.

Crepitant: C r e p i t a n t "a. Having a crackling sound; crackling; rattling.

Crepitate: C r e p i t a t e "v. To make a series of small  sharp rapidly repeated explosions or sounds as salt in fire; to crackle; to snap.

Crepitated: C r e p i t a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Crepitate

Crepitating: C r e p i t a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Crepitate

Crepitation: C r e p i t a t i o n "n. The act of crepitating or crackling.

Crepitation: C r e p i t a t i o n "n. A grating or crackling sensation or sound  as that produced by rubbing two fragments of a broken bone together or by pressing upon cellular tissue containing air.

Crepitation: C r e p i t a t i o n "n. A crepitant rale.

Crepitus: C r e p i t u s "n. The noise produced by a sudden discharge of wind from the bowels.

Crepitus: C r e p i t u s "n. Same as Crepitation  2.

Crepon: C r e p o n "n. A thin stuff made of the finest wool or silk  or of wool and silk.

Crepusculine: C r e p u s c u l i n e "a. Crepuscular.

Crepusculous: C r e p u s c u l o u s "a. Pertaining to twilight; glimmering; hence  imperfectly clear or luminous.

Crepusculous: C r e p u s c u l o u s "a. Flying in the twilight or evening  or before sunrise; -- said certain birds and insects.

Crescence: C r e s c e n c e "n. Increase; enlargement.

Crescendo: C r e s c e n d o "a. & adv. With a constantly increasing volume of voice; with gradually increasing strength and fullness of tone; -- a direction for the performance of music  indicated by the mark or by writing the word on the score.

Crescendo: C r e s c e n d o "n. A gradual increase in the strength and fullness of tone with which a passage is performed.

Crescendo: C r e s c e n d o "n. A passage to be performed with constantly increasing volume of tone.

Crescent: C r e s c e n t "n. The increasing moon; the moon in her first quarter  or when defined by a concave and a convex edge; also applied improperly to the old or decreasing moon in a like state.

Crescent: C r e s c e n t "n. Anything having the shape of a crescent or new moon.

Crescent: C r e s c e n t "n. A representation of the increasing moon  often used as an emblem or badge

Crescent: C r e s c e n t "n. A symbol of Artemis  or Diana.

Crescent: C r e s c e n t "n. The ancient symbol of Byzantium or Constantinople.

Crescent: C r e s c e n t "n. The emblem of the Turkish Empire  adopted after the taking of Constantinople.

Crescent: C r e s c e n t "n. Any one of three orders of knighthood; the first instituted by Charles I.  king of Naples and Sicily in 1268; the second by Rene of Anjou in 1448; and the third by the Sultan Selim III. in 1801 to be conferred upon foreigners to whom Turkey might be indebted for valuable services.

Crescent: C r e s c e n t "n. The emblem of the increasing moon with horns directed upward  when used in a coat of arms; -- often used as a mark of cadency to distinguish a second son and his descendants.

Crescent: C r e s c e n t "a. Shaped like a crescent.

Crescent: C r e s c e n t "a. Increasing; growing.

Crescent: C r e s c e n t "v. t. To form into a crescent  or something resembling a crescent.

Crescent: C r e s c e n t "v. t. To adorn with crescents.

Crescentic: C r e s c e n t i c "a. Crescent-shaped.

Crescentwise: C r e s c e n t w i s e "adv. In the form of a crescent; like a crescent.

Crescive: C r e s c i v e "a. Increasing; growing.

Cresol: C r e s o l "n. Any one of three metameric substances  CH3.C6H4.OH homologous with and resembling phenol. They are obtained from coal tar and wood tar and are colorless oily liquids or solids. [Called also cresylic acid.]

Cresorcin: C r e s o r c i n "n. Same as Isorcin.

Cress: C r e s s "n. A plant of various species  chiefly cruciferous. The leaves have a moderately pungent taste and are used as a salad and antiscorbutic.

Cresselle: C r e s s e l l e "n. A wooden rattle sometimes used as a substitute for a bell  in the Roman Catholic church during the latter part of Holy Week or the last week of Lent.

Cresses: C r e s s e s "pl. "of Cress

Cresset: C r e s s e t "n. An open frame or basket of iron  filled with combustible material to be burned as a beacon; an open lamp or firrepan carried on a pole in nocturnal processions.

Cresset: C r e s s e t "n. A small furnace or iron cage to hold fire for charring the inside of a cask  and making the staves flexible.

Cressy: C r e s s y "a. Abounding in cresses.

Crest: C r e s t "n. A tuft  or other excrescence or natural ornament growing on an animal's head; the comb of a cock; the swelling on the head of a serpent; the lengthened feathers of the crown or nape of bird etc.

Crest: C r e s t "n. The plume of feathers  or other decoration worn on a helmet; the distinctive ornament of a helmet indicating the rank of the wearer; hence also the helmet.

Crest: C r e s t "n. A bearing worn  not upon the shield but usually above it or separately as an ornament for plate liveries and the like. It is a relic of the ancient cognizance. See Cognizance 4.

Crest: C r e s t "n. The upper curve of a horse's neck.

Crest: C r e s t "n. The ridge or top of a wave.

Crest: C r e s t "n. The summit of a hill or mountain ridge.

Crest: C r e s t "n. The helm or head  as typical of a high spirit; pride; courage.

Crest: C r e s t "n. The top line of a slope or embankment.

Cretaceous: C r e t a c e o u s "a. Having the qualities of chalk; abounding with chalk; chalky; as  cretaceous rocks and formations. See Chalk.

Cretaceously: C r e t a c e o u s l y "adv. In a chalky manner; as chalk.

Cretian: C r e t i a n "a. & n. See Cretan.

Cretic: C r e t i c "n. A poetic foot  composed of one short syllable between two long ones (- / -).

Creticism: C r e t i c i s m "n. Falsehood; lying; cretism.

Cretin: C r e t i n "n. One afflicted with cretinism.

Cretinism: C r e t i n i s m "n. A condition of endemic or inherited idiocy  accompanied by physical degeneracy and deformity (usually with goiter) frequent in certain mountain valleys esp. of the Alps.

Cretinous: C r e t i n o u s "a. Having the characteristics of a cretin.

Cretism: C r e t i s m "n. A Cretan practice; lying; a falsehood.

Cretonne: C r e t o n n e "n. A strong white fabric with warp of hemp and weft of flax.

Cretonne: C r e t o n n e "n. A fabric with cotton warp and woolen weft.

Cretonne: C r e t o n n e "n. A kind of chintz with a glossy surface.

Cretor: C r e t o r "n. One who creates  produces or constitutes. Specifically the Supreme Being.

Cretose: C r e t o s e "a. Chalky; cretaceous.

Creutzer: C r e u t z e r "n. See Kreutzer.

Creux: C r e u x "n. Used in English only in the expression en creux. Thus  engraving en creux is engraving in intaglio or by sinking or hollowing out the design.

Crevalle: C r e v a l l e "n. The cavally or jurel.

Crevalle: C r e v a l l e "n. The pompano (Trachynotus Carolinus).

Crevasse: C r e v a s s e "n. A breach in the levee or embankment of a river  caused by the pressure of the water as on the lower Mississippi.

Crevet: C r e v e t "n. A crucible or melting pot; a cruset.

Crib: C r i b "n. A structure or frame of timber for a foundation  or for supporting a roof or for lining a shaft.

Crib: C r i b "n. A structure of logs to be anchored with stones; -- used for docks  pier dams etc.

Crib: C r i b "n. A small raft of timber.

Crib: C r i b "n. A small theft; anything purloined;; a plagiaris/; hence  a translation or key etc. to aid a student in preparing or reciting his lessons.

Crib: C r i b "n. A miner's luncheon.

Crib: C r i b "n. The discarded cards which the dealer can use in scoring points in cribbage.

Crib: C r i b "v. t. To shut up or confine in a narrow habitation; to cage; to cramp.

Crib: C r i b "v. t. To pilfer or purloin; hence  to steal from an author; to appropriate; to plagiarize; as to crib a line from Milton.

Crib: C r i b "v. i. To crowd together  or to be confined as in a crib or in narrow accommodations.

Crib: C r i b "v. i. To make notes for dishonest use in recitation or examination.

Crib: C r i b "v. i. To seize the manger or other solid object with the teeth and draw in wind; -- said of a horse.

Crib-biter: C r i b - b i t e r "n. A horse that has the habit of cribbing.

Crib-biting: C r i b - b i t i n g "n. Same as Cribbing  4.

Cribbage: C r i b b a g e "v. t. A game of cards  played by two or four persons in which there is a crib. (See Crib 11.) It is characterized by a great variety of chances.

Cribbed: C r i b b e d "imp. & p. p. of Crib

Cribbing: C r i b b i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Crib

Cribbing: C r i b b i n g "n. The act of inclosing or confining in a crib or in close quarters.

Cribbing: C r i b b i n g "n. Purloining; stealing; plagiarizing.

Cribbing: C r i b b i n g "n. A framework of timbers and plank backing for a shaft lining  to prevent caving percolation of water etc.

Cribbing: C r i b b i n g "n. A vicious habit of a horse; crib-biting. The horse lays hold of the crib or manger with his teeth and draws air into the stomach with a grunting sound.

Cribble: C r i b b l e "n. A coarse sieve or screen.

Cribble: C r i b b l e "n. Coarse flour or meal.

Cribration: C r i b r a t i o n "n. The act or process of separating the finer parts of drugs from the coarser by sifting.

Cribriform: C r i b r i f o r m "a. Resembling  or having the form of a sieve; pierced with holes; as the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone; a cribriform compress.

Cribrose: C r i b r o s e "a. Perforated like a sieve; cribriform.

Cric: C r i c "n. The ring which turns inward and condenses the flame of a lamp.

Crick: C r i c k "n. The creaking of a door  or a noise resembling it.

Crick: C r i c k "n. A painful  spasmodic affection of the muscles of some part of the body as of the neck or back rendering it difficult to move the part.

Crick: C r i c k "n. A small jackscrew.

Cricket: C r i c k e t "n. An orthopterous insect of the genus Gryllus  and allied genera. The males make chirping musical notes by rubbing together the basal parts of the veins of the front wings.

Cricket: C r i c k e t "n. A low stool.

Cricket: C r i c k e t "n. A game much played in England  and sometimes in America with a ball bats and wickets the players being arranged in two contesting parties or sides.

Cricket: C r i c k e t "n. A small false roof  or the raising of a portion of a roof so as to throw off water from behind an obstacle such as a chimney.

Cricket: C r i c k e t "v. i. To play at cricket.

Cricketer: C r i c k e t e r "n. One who plays at cricket.

Cries: C r i e s "pl. "of Cry

Crime: C r i m e "n. Any violation of law  either divine or human; an omission of a duty commanded or the commission of an act forbidden by law.

Crime: C r i m e "n. Gross violation of human law  in distinction from a misdemeanor or trespass or other slight offense. Hence also any aggravated offense against morality or the public welfare; any outrage or great wrong.

Crime: C r i m e "n. Any great wickedness or sin; iniquity.

Crime: C r i m e "n. That which occasion crime.

Crimeful: C r i m e f u l "a. Criminal; wicked; contrary to law  right or dury.

Crimeless: C r i m e l e s s "a. Free from crime; innocent.

Criminal: C r i m i n a l "a. Guilty of crime or sin.

Criminal: C r i m i n a l "a. Involving a crime; of the nature of a crime; -- said of an act or of conduct; as  criminal carelessness.

Criminal: C r i m i n a l "a. Relating to crime; -- opposed to civil; as  the criminal code.

Criminal: C r i m i n a l "n. One who has commited a crime; especially  one who is found guilty by verdict confession or proof; a malefactor; a felon.

Criminalist: C r i m i n a l i s t "n. One versed in criminal law.

Criminality: C r i m i n a l i t y "n. The quality or state of being criminal; that which constitutes a crime; guiltiness; guilt.

Criminally: C r i m i n a l l y "adv. In violation of law; wickedly.

Criminalness: C r i m i n a l n e s s "n. Criminality.

Criminate: C r i m i n a t e "v. t. "To accuse of  or charge with a crime.

Criminative: C r i m i n a t i v e "a. Charging with crime; accusing; criminatory.

Criminology: C r i m i n o l o g y "n. A treatise on crime or the criminal population.

Criminous: C r i m i n o u s "a. Criminal; involving great crime or grave charges; very wicked; heinous.

Crimosin: C r i m o s i n "n. See Crimson.

Crimp: C r i m p "v. t. To fold or plait in regular undulation in such a way that the material will retain the shape intended; to give a wavy appearance to; as  to crimp the border of a cap; to crimp a ruffle. Cf. Crisp.

Crimp: C r i m p "v. t. To pinch and hold; to seize.

Crimp: C r i m p "v. t. to entrap into the military or naval service; as  to crimp seamen.

Crimp: C r i m p "v. t. To cause to contract  or to render more crisp as the flesh of a fish by gashing it when living with a knife; as to crimp skate etc.

Crimp: C r i m p "a. Easily crumbled; friable; brittle.

Crimp: C r i m p "a. Weak; inconsistent; contradictory.

Crimp: C r i m p "n. A coal broker.

Crimp: C r i m p "n. One who decoys or entraps men into the military or naval service.

Crimp: C r i m p "n. A keeper of a low lodging house where sailors and emigrants are entrapped and fleeced.

Crimp: C r i m p "n. Hair which has been crimped; -- usually in pl.

Crimp: C r i m p "n. A game at cards.

Crimpage: C r i m p a g e "n. The act or practice of crimping; money paid to a crimp for shipping or enlisting men.

Crinel: C r i n e l "n. Alt. of Crinet

Crinet: C r i n e t "n. A very fine  hairlike feather.

Cringe: C r i n g e "v. t. To draw one's self together as in fear or servility; to bend or crouch with base humility; to wince; hence; to make court in a degrading manner; to fawn.

Cringe: C r i n g e "v. t. To contract; to draw together; to cause to shrink or wrinkle; to distort.

Cringe: C r i n g e "n. Servile civility; fawning; a shrinking or bowing  as in fear or servility.

Cringeling: C r i n g e l i n g "n. One who cringes meanly; a fawner.

Cringer: C r i n g e r "n. One who cringes.

Cringing: C r i n g i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Cringe

Cringingly: C r i n g i n g l y "adv. In a cringing manner.

Cringle: C r i n g l e "n. A withe for fastening a gate.

Cringle: C r i n g l e "n. An iron or pope thimble or grommet worked into or attached to the edges and corners of a sail; -- usually in the plural. The cringles are used for making fast the bowline bridles  earings etc.

Crinicultural: C r i n i c u l t u r a l "a. Relating to the growth of hair.

Crinigerous: C r i n i g e r o u s "a. Bearing hair; hairy.

Crinital: C r i n i t a l "a. Same as Crinite  1.

Crinite: C r i n i t e "a. Having the appearance of a tuft of hair; having a hairlike tail or train.

Crinite: C r i n i t e "a. Bearded or tufted with hairs.

Crinitory: C r i n i t o r y "a. Of or relating to hair; as  a crinitory covering.

Crinkle: C r i n k l e "v. t. To form with short turns  bends or wrinkles; to mold into inequalities or sinuosities; to cause to wrinkle or curl.

Crinkle: C r i n k l e "v. i. To turn or wind; to run in and out in many short bends or turns; to curl; to run in waves; to wrinkle; also  to rustle as stiff cloth when moved.

Crinkle: C r i n k l e "n. A winding or turn; wrinkle; sinuosity.

Crinkled: C r i n k l e d "imp. & p. p. of Crinkle

Crinkled: C r i n k l e d "a. Having short bends  turns or wrinkles; wrinkled; wavy; zigzag.

Crinoid: C r i n o i d "a. Crinoidal.

Crinoid: C r i n o i d "n. One of the Crinoidea.

Crinoidal: C r i n o i d a l "a. Of pertaining to crinoids; consisting of  or containing crinoids.

Crinoidea: C r i n o i d e a "n. pl. A large class of Echinodermata  including numerous extinct families and genera but comparatively few living ones. Most of the fossil species like some that are recent were attached by a jointed stem. See Blastoidea Cystoidea Comatula.

Crinoidean: C r i n o i d e a n "n. One of the Crinoidea.

Crinoline: C r i n o l i n e "n. A kind of stiff cloth  used chiefly by women for underskirts to expand the gown worn over it; -- so called because originally made of hair.

Crinoline: C r i n o l i n e "n. A lady's skirt made of any stiff material; latterly  a hoop skirt.

Crinose: C r i n o s e "a. Hairy.

Crinosity: C r i n o s i t y "n. Hairiness.

Crinum: C r i n u m "n. A genus of bulbous plants  of the order Amaryllidace/ cultivated as greenhouse plants on account of their beauty.

Criosphinx: C r i o s p h i n x "n. A sphinx with the head of a ram.

Cripple: C r i p p l e "n. One who creeps  halts or limps; one who has lost or never had the use of a limb or limbs; a lame person; hence one who is partially disabled.

Cripple: C r i p p l e "a. Lame; halting.

Cripple: C r i p p l e "v. t. To deprive of the use of a limb  particularly of a leg or foot; to lame.

Cripple: C r i p p l e "v. t. To deprive of strength  activity or capability for service or use; to disable; to deprive of resources; as to be financially crippled.

Crippled: C r i p p l e d "a. Lamed; lame; disabled; impeded.

Crippler: C r i p p l e r "n. A wooden tool used in graining leather.

Crippling: C r i p p l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Cripple

Crippling: C r i p p l i n g "n. Spars or timbers set up as a support against the side of a building.

Cripply: C r i p p l y "a. Lame; disabled; in a crippled condition.

Crises: C r i s e s "pl. "of Crisis

Crisis: C r i s i s "n. The point of time when it is to be decided whether any affair or course of action must go on  or be modified or terminate; the decisive moment; the turning point.

Crisis: C r i s i s "n. That change in a disease which indicates whether the result is to be recovery or death; sometimes  also a striking change of symptoms attended by an outward manifestation as by an eruption or sweat.

Crisp: C r i s p "a. Curling in stiff curls or ringlets; as  crisp hair.

Crisp: C r i s p "a. Curled with the ripple of the water.

Crisp: C r i s p "a. Brittle; friable; in a condition to break with a short  sharp fracture; as crisp snow.

Crisp: C r i s p "a. Possessing a certain degree of firmness and freshness; in a fresh  unwilted condition.

Crisp: C r i s p "a. Lively; sparking; effervescing.

Crisp: C r i s p "a. Brisk; crackling; cheerful; lively.

Crisp: C r i s p "a. To curl; to form into ringlets  as hair or the nap of cloth; to interweave as the branches of trees.

Crisp: C r i s p "a. To cause to undulate irregularly  as crape or water; to wrinkle; to cause to ripple. Cf. Crimp.

Crisp: C r i s p "a. To make crisp or brittle  as in cooking.

Crisp: C r i s p "v. i. To undulate or ripple. Cf. Crisp  v. t.

Crisp: C r i s p "n. That which is crisp or brittle; the state of being crisp or brittle; as  burned to a crisp; specifically the rind of roasted pork; crackling.

Crispate: C r i s p a t e "a. Alt. of Crispated

Crispated: C r i s p a t e d "a. Having a crisped appearance; irregularly curled or twisted.

Crispation: C r i s p a t i o n "n. The act or process of curling  or the state of being curled.

Crispation: C r i s p a t i o n "n. A very slight convulsive or spasmodic contraction of certain muscles  external or internal.

Crispature: C r i s p a t u r e "n. The state of being crispate.

Crisped: C r i s p e d "imp. & p. p. of Crisp

Crisper: C r i s p e r "n. One who  or that which crisps or curls; an instrument for making little curls in the nap of cloth as in chinchilla.

Crispin: C r i s p i n "n. A shoemaker; -- jocularly so called from the patron saint of the craft.

Crispin: C r i s p i n "n. A member of a union or association of shoemakers.

Crisping: C r i s p i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Crisp

Crisply: C r i s p l y "adv. In a crisp manner.

Crispness: C r i s p n e s s "n. The state or quality of being crisp.

Crispy: C r i s p y "a. Formed into short  close ringlets; frizzed; crisp; as crispy locks.

Crispy: C r i s p y "a. Crisp; brittle; as  a crispy pie crust.

Crissa: C r i s s a "pl. "of Crissum

Crissal: C r i s s a l "a. Pertaining to the crissum; as  crissal feathers.

Crissal: C r i s s a l "a. Having highly colored under tail coverts; as  the crissal thrasher.

Crisscross: C r i s s c r o s s "n. A mark or cross  as the signature of a person who is unable to write.

Crisscross: C r i s s c r o s s "n. A child's game played on paper or on a slate  consisting of lines arranged in the form of a cross.

Crisscross: C r i s s c r o s s "v. t. To mark or cover with cross lines; as  a paper was crisscrossed with red marks.

Crisscross: C r i s s c r o s s "adv. In opposite directions; in a way to cross something else; crossing one another at various angles and in various ways.

Crisscross: C r i s s c r o s s "adv. With opposition or hindrance; at cross purposes; contrarily; as  things go crisscross.

Crissum: C r i s s u m "n. That part of a bird  or the feathers surrounding the cloacal opening; the under tail coverts.

Cristallology: C r i s t a l l o l o g y "n. The science of the crystalline structure of inorganic bodies.

Cristate: C r i s t a t e "a. Crested.

Criteria: C r i t e r i a "pl. "of Criterion

Criterion: C r i t e r i o n "n. A standard of judging; any approved or established rule or test  by which facts principles opinions and conduct are tried in forming a correct judgment respecting them.

Criterions: C r i t e r i o n s "pl. "of Criterion

Crith: C r i t h "n. The unit for estimating the weight of a/riform substances; -- the weight of a liter of hydrogen at 0/ centigrade  and with a tension of 76 centimeters of mercury. It is 0.0896 of a gram or 1.38274 grains.

Crithomancu: C r i t h o m a n c u "n. A kind of divination by means of the dough of the cakes offered in the ancient sacrifices  and the meal strewed over the victims.

Critic: C r i t i c "n. One skilled in judging of the merits of literary or artistic works; a connoisseur; an adept; hence  one who examines literary or artistic works etc. and passes judgment upon them; a reviewer.

Critic: C r i t i c "n. One who passes a rigorous or captious judgment; one who censures or finds fault; a harsh examiner or judge; a caviler; a carper.

Critic: C r i t i c "n. The art of criticism.

Critic: C r i t i c "n. An act of criticism; a critique.

Critic: C r i t i c "a. Of or pertaining to critics or criticism; critical.

Critic: C r i t i c "v. i. To criticise; to play the critic.

Critical: C r i t i c a l "n. Qualified to criticise  or pass judgment upon literary or artistic productions.

Critical: C r i t i c a l "n. Pertaining to criticism or the critic's art; of the nature of a criticism; accurate; as  critical knowledge; a critical dissertation.

Critical: C r i t i c a l "n. Inclined to make nice distinctions  or to exercise careful judgment and selection; exact; nicely judicious.

Critical: C r i t i c a l "n. Inclined to criticise or find fault; fastidious; captious; censorious; exacting.

Critical: C r i t i c a l "n. Characterized by thoroughness and a reference to principles  as becomes a critic; as a critical analysis of a subject.

Critical: C r i t i c a l "n. Pertaining to  or indicating a crisis turning point or specially important juncture; important as regards consequences; hence of doubtful issue; attended with risk; dangerous; as the critical stage of a fever; a critical situation.

Critically: C r i t i c a l l y "adv. In a critical manner; with nice discernment; accurately; exactly.

Critically: C r i t i c a l l y "adv. At a crisis; at a critical time; in a situation  place or condition of decisive consequence; as a fortification critically situated.

Criticalness: C r i t i c a l n e s s "n. The state or quality of being critical  or of occurring at a critical time.

Criticalness: C r i t i c a l n e s s "n. Accuracy in examination or decision; exactness.

Criticaster: C r i t i c a s t e r "n. A contemptible or vicious critic.

Criticisable: C r i t i c i s a b l e "a. Capable of being criticised.

Criticise: C r i t i c i s e "v. t. To examine and judge as a critic; to pass literary or artistic judgment upon; as  to criticise an author; to criticise a picture.

Criticise: C r i t i c i s e "v. t. To express one's views as to the merit or demerit of; esp.  to animadvert upon; to find fault with; as to criticise conduct.

Criticise: C r i t i c i s e "v. i. To act as a critic; to pass literary or artistic judgment; to play the critic; -- formerly used with on or upon.

Criticise: C r i t i c i s e "v. i. To discuss the merits or demerits of a thing or person; esp.  to find fault.

Criticised: C r i t i c i s e d "imp. & p. p. of Criticise

Criticiser: C r i t i c i s e r "n. One who criticises; a critic.

Criticising: C r i t i c i s i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Criticise

Criticism: C r i t i c i s m "n. The rules and principles which regulate the practice of the critic; the art of judging with knowledge and propriety of the beauties and faults of a literary performance  or of a production in the fine arts; as dramatic criticism.

Criticism: C r i t i c i s m "n. The act of criticising; a critical judgment passed or expressed; a critical observation or detailed examination and review; a critique; animadversion; censure.

Critique: C r i t i q u e "n. The art of criticism.

Critique: C r i t i q u e "n. A critical examination or estimate of a work of literature or art; a critical dissertation or essay; a careful and through analysis of any subject; a criticism; as  Kant's Critique of Pure Reason.

Critique: C r i t i q u e "n. A critic; one who criticises.

Critique: C r i t i q u e "v. To criticise or pass judgment upon.

Crizzel: C r i z z e l "n. A kind of roughness on the surface of glass  which clouds its transparency.

Cro-quette: C r o - q u e t t e "n. A ball of minced meat  fowl rice or other ingredients highly seasoned and fried.

Croak: C r o a k "v. i. To make a low  hoarse noise in the throat as a frog a raven or a crow; hence to make any hoarse dismal sound.

Croak: C r o a k "v. i. To complain; especially  to grumble; to forebode evil; to utter complaints or forebodings habitually.

Croak: C r o a k "v. t. To utter in a low  hoarse voice; to announce by croaking; to forebode; as to croak disaster.

Croak: C r o a k "n. The coarse  harsh sound uttered by a frog or a raven or a like sound.

Croaked: C r o a k e d "imp. & p. p. of Croak

Croaker: C r o a k e r "n. One who croaks  murmurs grumbles or complains unreasonably; one who habitually forebodes evil.

Croaker: C r o a k e r "n. A small American fish (Micropogon undulatus)  of the Atlantic coast.

Croaker: C r o a k e r "n. An American fresh-water fish (Aplodinotus grunniens); -- called also drum.

Croaker: C r o a k e r "n. The surf fish of California.

Croaking: C r o a k i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Croak

Croat: C r o a t "n. A native of Croatia  in Austria; esp. one of the native Slavic race.

Croat: C r o a t "n. An irregular soldier  generally from Croatia.

Croatian: C r o a t i a n "a. Of or pertaining to Croatia.

Croatian: C r o a t i a n "n. A Croat.

Crocein: C r o c e i n "n. A name given to any one of several yellow or scarlet dyestuffs of artificial production and complex structure. In general they are diazo and sulphonic acid derivatives of benzene and naphthol.

Croceous: C r o c e o u s "a. Of  pertaining to or like saffron; deep reddish yellow.

Crocetin: C r o c e t i n "n. A dyestuff  obtained from the Chinese crocin which produces a brilliant yellow.

Croche: C r o c h e "n. A little bud or knob at the top of a deer's antler.

Crochet: C r o c h e t "n. A kind of knitting done by means of a hooked needle  with worsted silk or cotton; crochet work. Commonly used adjectively.

Crochet: C r o c h e t "v. t. & i. To knit with a crochet needle or hook; as  to crochet a shawl.

Crocheted: C r o c h e t e d "imp. & p. p. of Crochet

Crocheting: C r o c h e t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Crochet

Crociary: C r o c i a r y "n. One who carries the cross before an archbishop.

Crocidolite: C r o c i d o l i t e "n. A mineral occuring in silky fibers of a lavender blue color. It is related to hornblende and is essentially a silicate of iron and soda; -- called also blue asbestus. A silicified form  in which the fibers penetrating quartz are changed to oxide of iron is the yellow brown tiger-eye of the jewelers.

Crocin: C r o c i n "n. The coloring matter of Chinese yellow pods  the fruit of Gardenia grandiflora.

Crocin: C r o c i n "n. A red powder (called also polychroite)  which is made from the saffron (Crocus sativus). See Polychroite.

Crock: C r o c k "n. The loose black particles collected from combustion  as on pots and kettles or in a chimney; soot; smut; also coloring matter which rubs off from cloth.

Crock: C r o c k "v. t. To soil by contact  as with soot or with the coloring matter of badly dyed cloth.

Crock: C r o c k "v. i. To give off crock or smut.

Crock: C r o c k "n. A low stool.

Crock: C r o c k "n. Any piece of crockery  especially of coarse earthenware; an earthen pot or pitcher.

Crock: C r o c k "v. t. To lay up in a crock; as  to crock butter.

Crocked: C r o c k e d "imp. & p. p. of Crock

Crocker: C r o c k e r "n. A potter.

Crockery: C r o c k e r y "n. Earthenware; vessels formed of baked clay  especially the coarser kinds.

Crocket: C r o c k e t "n. An ornament often resembling curved and bent foliage  projecting from the sloping edge of a gable spire etc.

Crocket: C r o c k e t "n. A croche  or knob on the top of a stag's antler.

Crocketed: C r o c k e t e d "a. Ornamented with crockets.

Crocketing: C r o c k e t i n g "n. Ornamentation with crockets.

Crocking: C r o c k i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Crock

Crocky: C r o c k y "a. Smutty.

Crocodile: C r o c o d i l e "n. A large reptile of the genus Crocodilus  of several species. They grow to the length of sixteen or eighteen feet and inhabit the large rivers of Africa Asia and America. The eggs laid in the sand are hatched by the sun's heat. The best known species is that of the Nile (C. vulgaris or C. Niloticus). The Florida crocodile (C. Americanus) is much less common than the alligator and has longer jaws. The name is also sometimes applied to the species of other related genera as the gavial and the alligator.

Crocodile: C r o c o d i l e "n. A fallacious dilemma  mythically supposed to have been first used by a crocodile.

Crocodilia: C r o c o d i l i a "n. pl. An order of reptiles including the crocodiles  gavials alligators and many extinct kinds.

Crocodilian: C r o c o d i l i a n "a. Like  or pertaining to the crocodile; characteristic of the crocodile.

Crocodilian: C r o c o d i l i a n "n. One of the Crocodilia.

Crocodility: C r o c o d i l i t y "n. A caption or sophistical mode of arguing.

Crocoisite: C r o c o i s i t e "n. Same as Crocoite.

Crocoite: C r o c o i t e "n. Lead chromate occuring in crystals of a bright hyacinth red color; -- called also red lead ore.

Croconate: C r o c o n a t e "n. A salt formed by the union of croconic acid with a base.

Croconic: C r o c o n i c "a. Of  pertaining to or resembling saffron; having the color of saffron; as croconic acid.

Croconic: C r o c o n i c "a. Pertaining to  or derived from croconic acid.

Crocose: C r o c o s e "n. A white crystalline sugar  metameric with glucose obtained from the coloring matter of saffron.

Crocus: C r o c u s "n. A genus of iridaceous plants  with pretty blossoms rising separately from the bulb or corm. C. vernus is one of the earliest of spring-blooming flowers; C. sativus produces the saffron and blossoms in the autumn.

Crocus: C r o c u s "n. A deep yellow powder; the oxide of some metal calcined to a red or deep yellow color; esp.  the oxide of iron (Crocus of Mars or colcothar) thus produced from salts of iron and used as a polishing powder.

Croesus: C r o e s u s "n. A king of Lydia who flourished in the 6th century b. c.  and was renowned for his vast wealth; hence a common appellation for a very rich man; as he is a veritable Croesus.

Croft: C r o f t "n. A small  inclosed field adjoining a house; a small farm.

Crofter: C r o f t e r "n. One who rents and tills a small farm or helding; as  the crofters of Scotland.

Croftland: C r o f t l a n d "n. Land of superior quality  on which successive crops are raised.

Crois: C r o i s "n. See Cross  n.

Croisade: C r o i s a d e "n. Alt. of Croisado

Croisado: C r o i s a d o "n. A holy war; a crusade.

Croise: C r o i s e "n. A pilgrim bearing or wearing a cross.

Croise: C r o i s e "n. A crusader.

Croissante: C r o i s s a n t e "a. Terminated with crescent; -- said of a cross the ends of which are so terminated.

Croker: C r o k e r "n. A cultivator of saffron; a dealer in saffron.

Croma: C r o m a "n. A quaver.

Cromlech: C r o m l e c h "n. A monument of rough stones composed of one or more large ones supported in a horizontal position upon others. They are found chiefly in countries inhabited by the ancient Celts  and are of a period anterior to the introduction of Christianity into these countries.

Cromorna: C r o m o r n a "n. A certain reed stop in the organ  of a quality of tone resembling that of the oboe.

Crone: C r o n e "n. An old ewe.

Crone: C r o n e "n. An old woman; -- usually in contempt.

Crone: C r o n e "n. An old man; especially  a man who talks and acts like an old woman.

Cronel: C r o n e l "n. The iron head of a tilting spear.

Cronet: C r o n e t "n. The coronet of a horse.

Cronian: C r o n i a n "a. Saturnian; -- applied to the North Polar Sea.

Cronies: C r o n i e s "pl. "of Crony

Cronstedtite: C r o n s t e d t i t e "n. A mineral consisting principally of silicate of iron  and crystallizing in hexagonal prisms with perfect basal cleavage; -- so named from the Swedish mineralogist Cronstedt.

Crony: C r o n y "n. A crone.

Crony: C r o n y "n. An intimate companion; a familiar frend

Crook: C r o o k "n. A bend  turn or curve; curvature; flexure.

Crook: C r o o k "n. Any implement having a bent or crooked end.

Crook: C r o o k "n. The staff used by a shepherd  the hook of which serves to hold a runaway sheep.

Crook: C r o o k "n. An artifice; trick; tricky device; subterfuge.

Crook: C r o o k "n. A person given to fraudulent practices; an accomplice of thieves  forgers etc.

Crook: C r o o k "n. To turn from a straight line; to bend; to curve.

Crook: C r o o k "v. i. To bend; to curve; to wind; to have a curvature.

Crookack: C r o o k a c k "a. Hunched.

Crookback: C r o o k b a c k "n. A crooked back; one who has a crooked or deformed back; a hunchback.

Crookbill: C r o o k b i l l "n. A New Zealand plover (Anarhynchus frontalis)  remarkable for having the end of the beak abruptly bent to the right.

Crooked: C r o o k e d "imp. & p. p. of Crook

Crooked: C r o o k e d "a. Characterized by a crook or curve; not straight; turning; bent; twisted; deformed.

Crooked: C r o o k e d "a. Not straightforward; deviating from rectitude; distorted from the right.

Crooked: C r o o k e d "a. False; dishonest; fraudulent; as  crooked dealings.

Crookedly: C r o o k e d l y "adv. In a curved or crooked manner; in a perverse or untoward manner.

Crookedness: C r o o k e d n e s s "n. The condition or quality of being crooked; hence  deformity of body or of mind; deviation from moral rectitude; perverseness.

Crooken: C r o o k e n "v. t. To make crooked.

Crookes tube: C r o o k e s   t u b e " A vacuum tube in which the exhaustion is carried to a very high degree  with the production of a distinct class of effects; -- so called from W. Crookes who introduced it.

Croon: C r o o n "v. i. To make a continuous hollow moan  as cattle do when in pain.

Croon: C r o o n "v. i. To hum or sing in a low tone; to murmur softly.

Croon: C r o o n "v. t. To soothe by singing softly.
